page.title: Template:Monthly clean-up category/Messages/Type/Article sections to be split

revision.text: This category combines all articles with sections that have been proposed to be [[WP:SPLIT|split]], from {{{month name|}}} {{{year|}}} ({{{year}}}-{{{monthno|}}}) to enable us to {{#ifeq:{{{clean-up|}}}|no|maintain them|work through the backlog}} more systematically. It is a member of [[:Category:{{{cat}}}]].

== Summary == {{Non-free use rationale |Article = Daddio |Description = Main Cast of Daddio |Source = [http://sharetv.org/shows/daddio] |Portion = no |Low_resolution = The image is rendered in low resolution to avoid piracy. Copies made from it will be unsuitable for uses that would compete with the commercial purpose of the original image. |Purpose = It is used for identification in the context of critical commentary of the programme it depicts. It makes a significant contribution to the user's understanding of the article, which could not practically be conveyed by words alone. It shows a primary visual image associated with the programme to help the user quickly identify the programme and know they have found what they are looking for. |Replaceability = As the programme is protected by copyright, no free equivalent exists that would effectively identify it. |other_information = It is copyright of [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]]. }} == Licensing == {{Non-free promotional|image_has_rationale=yes|image_is_of_living_person=yes}}

{{Infobox ice hockey player | image_size = 230px | alt = | name = Marius M√∂chel | image = 2015 Nuernberg Icetigers - Marius Moechel - by 2eight - DSC4084.jpg | caption = | size = 230px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|05|28}} | birth_place = [[Nuremberg]], [[Germany]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 3 | weight_lbs = 187 | position = [[Forward (ice hockey)|Forward]] | shoots = Left | league = [[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|DEL]] | team = [[Grizzlys Wolfsburg]] | former_teams = [[EHC M√ºnchen]]
[[Hamburg Freezers]]
[[Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers]] | draft = | career_start = 2011 | career_end = }} '''Marius M√∂chel''' (born May 28, 1991) is a [[Germany|German]] professional [[ice hockey]] player. He is currently playing for the [[Grizzlys Wolfsburg]] in the [[Deutsche Eishockey Liga]] (DEL).{{DEL profile|5163411|Marius M√∂chel}} He has formerly played in the DEL with [[EHC M√ºnchen]], [[Hamburg Freezers]] and the [[Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hamburg-freezers.de/index.php?link=http://www.hamburg-freezers.de/html/freezers_team_spieler20132014.html |title=2013/2014 ''Spieler'' |trans-title=Players |language=German |publisher=[[Hamburg Freezers]] |accessdate=2013-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203010157/http://www.hamburg-freezers.de/index.php?link=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hamburg-freezers.de%2Fhtml%2Ffreezers_team_spieler20132014.html |archivedate=2013-12-03 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://del.stats.pointstreak.com/teamplayerstats.html?teamid=92239&seasonid=7325 |title=Hamburg Freezers 2011/2012 Roster |publisher=Pointstreak.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924013815/http://del.stats.pointstreak.com/teamplayerstats.html?teamid=92239&seasonid=7325 |archivedate=September 24, 2011 }} After four seasons with the Ice Tigers, M√∂chel left following the [[2017-18 DEL season|2017‚Äì18]] campaign, signing a two-year contract with his fourth DEL club, in Grizzzlys Wolfsburg, on April 17, 2018.{{citeweb| url = https://www.grizzlys.de/news_867.html | title = Marius Mochel becomes a Grizzly | publisher = ''[[Grizzlys Wolfsburg]]'' |date = 2018-04-17 | accessdate = 2018-04-17 | language = German}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{icehockeystats}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mochel, Marius}} [[Category:1991 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hamburg Freezers players]] [[Category:German ice hockey players]] [[Category:EHC M√ºnchen players]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Nuremberg]] [[Category:Star Bulls Rosenheim players]] [[Category:Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers players]] [[Category:EHC Wolfsburg players]] {{Germany-icehockey-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = ''Cancellicula'' | fossil_range = | image = | image_caption = | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Mollusca]] | classis = [[Gastropoda]] | unranked_superfamilia= clade [[Caenogastropoda]]
clade [[Hypsogastropoda]]
clade [[Neogastropoda]] | superfamilia = [[Cancellarioidea]] | familia = [[Cancellariidae]] | subfamilia = [[Admetinae]] | genus = '''''Cancellicula''''' | genus_authority = Tabanelli, 2008 | subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] | subdivision = ''See text'' | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = }} '''''Cancellicula''''' is a [[genus]] of medium-sized [[sea snail]]s, [[Marine (ocean)|marine]] [[gastropod]] [[mollusc]]s in the family [[Cancellariidae]], the nutmeg snails.Bouchet, P. (2011). Cancellicula Tabanelli, 2008. Accessed through: World Register of Marine Species at http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=574347 on 2011-10-23 ==Species== According to the [[World Register of Marine Species]] (WoRMS), the following species with valid names are within the genus ''Cancellicula'' : * ''[[Cancellicula aethiopica]]'' (Thiele, 1925) * ''[[Cancellicula jonasi]]'' (de Barros & Petit, 2007) * ''[[Cancellicula microscopica]]'' (Dall, 1889) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q5031378}} [[Category:Cancellariidae]] {{cancellariidae-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox politician | name = Slim Riahi | native_name = ÿ≥ŸÑŸäŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ±Ÿäÿßÿ≠Ÿä | native_name_lang = aeb | nationality = [[Tunisia]]n | image = SlimRiahiANC2011.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|07|13|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bizerte]], [[Tunisia]] | alma_mater = [[University of Tripoli]] | party = [[Call of Tunisia]] (2018-present){{cite news|title=Nidaa Tounes Appoints Riahi Secretary-General|url=https://aawsat.com/english/home/article/1432681/nidaa-tounes-appoints-riahi-secretary-general|accessdate=7 March 2019|work=[[Asharq Al-Awsat]]|date=20 October 2018}}
[[Free Patriotic Union]] (2011-2018) | spouse = Sabah Aloui }} '''Slim Riahi''' ({{lang-ar|ÿ≥ŸÑŸäŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ±Ÿäÿßÿ≠Ÿä}}; born 1972) is a [[Tunisia]]n businessman and politician. He was the founder and leader of the [[Free Patriotic Union]] (UPL).{{cite news|author=Afef Abrougui|title=Tunisian media in flux since revolution|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/02/tunisian-media-flux-since-revolution-2014224125838691954.html|accessdate=17 October 2014|work=Al Jazeera|date=19 April 2014}} ==Biography== Slim Riahi was born on 13 July 1972 in [[Bizerte]], Tunisia. In 1980, his family went into exile in [[Libya]], as his father was an [[Arab nationalism|Arab nationalist]] opposed to President [[Habib Bourguiba]], as well as to his successor [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]]. Slim Riahi grew up in Libya. He studied management at the [[University of Tripoli|Al Fateh University]] in Tripoli.{{Citation|author=Yasmine Ryan|title=Tunisian newcomer spends big on campaign|work=Al Jazeera|date=21 October 2011 |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/10/201110217015351417.html|accessdate=23 October 2011}} Then, he engaged in the [[extraction of petroleum|oil production]], [[energy supply|energy]], [[aviation]] and [[real estate development|property development]] industries, which acquired him great wealth, worth billions.{{Citation|author=Radhouane Somai|title=Tunisie - Qui est Slim Riahi et que p√®se-t-il sur l‚Äô√©chiquier politique|work=Business News|date=22 August 2011 |language=French|url=http://www.businessnews.com.tn/Tunisie---Qui-est-Slim-Riahi-et-que-p%C3%83%C2%A8se-t-il-sur-l%C3%82%E2%80%99%C3%83%C2%A9chiquier-politique,519,26258,1|accessdate=23 October 2011}} Later, he moved to [[London]], and holds dual [[United Kingdom|British]] and Tunisian citizenship. Returning to Tunisia after the [[Tunisian revolution]] in January 2011, he founded a political party, the [[Free Patriotic Union]] (UPL), which promotes an [[economic liberalism|economically liberal]] and modernist program and positions itself at the [[centrism|centre]] of the political spectrum.{{Citation|author=Sam Bollier |title=Who are Tunisia's political parties?|work=Al Jazeera|date=9 October 2011 |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/10/201110614579390256.html|accessdate=22 October 2011}} The party run into controversy for mingling political and business interests, extensive campaigning and unclear financial resources.{{Citation|author=Eileen Byrne |title=Tunisia party runs into controversy|newspaper=Financial Times|date=27 September 2011|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/27c5d0aa-ddeb-11e0-a391-00144feabdc0.html?ftcamp=rss#axzz1bbP7AOEB|accessdate=23 October 2011}} In August 2011, Riahi announced that he was planning to enter into Tunisia's media business with acquiring a 20-percent stake of the newspaper publisher ''Dar Assabah''. He also established three TV stations, namely Ettounsiya Al-Oula, Ettounsiya Sport and Ettounsiya News. He advertised to become the president of [[Club Africain]] on 6 June 2012 and his love for Club Africain made him the president of the club..{{Citation |first=Amine|last=Lassouad|title= Slim Riahi au parc A et √† Bab Jedid|publisher=Kawarji|date=6 June 2012 |url=http://www.kawarji.com/actu-7217-divers_club_africain_slim_riahi_au_parc_a_et_a_bab_jedid.html|accessdate=6 June 2012}} He was officially confirmed as the new president of Club Africain on 16 June 2012.{{Citation|author=Mohammed Agrebi|title=Slim Riahi est le nouveau pr√©sident du Club Africain|work= Kawarji|date=16 June 2012 |url=http://www.kawarji.com/actu-7397-ligue_1_slim_riahi_est_le_nouveau_president_du_club_africain.html|accessdate=16 June 2012}} On 28 June 2017, his assets was frozen by the Tunis Court of First Instance on suspicion of money laundering.{{cite web|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20170630-tunisia-freezes-assets-of-opposition-leader/|title=Tunisia freezes assets of opposition leader|publisher=Middle East Monitor|date=30 June 2017}} Riahi is in self-imposed [[exile]] in the [[United Arab Emirates]] following the issuing of a five year jail sentence against him for issuing checks without balance, as well as corruption related to his leading the Tunisian sports club [[Club Africain]].{{cite web|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20190215-nidaa-tounes-leader-addresses-opponents-from-uae-exile/|title=Nidaa Tounes leader addresses opponents from UAE exile|publisher=[[Middle East Monitor]]|date=15 February 2019|accessdate=7 March 2019|}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111024030447/http://www.upl.tn/une-equipe-jeune/ Presentation on the UPL's website] (in French) {{DEFAULTSORT:Riahi, Slim}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Sousse Governorate]] [[Category:Free Patriotic Union politicians]] [[Category:Nidaa Tounes politicians]] [[Category:Tunisian businesspeople]] [[Category:Tunisian expatriates in Libya]] [[Category:Tunisian expatriates in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox horseracing personality | name = Georges Stern | image = | caption = | occupation = [[Jockey]] | birth_date = 1882 | birth_place = France | death_date = October 1928 | death_place = France | career wins = | race = | awards = | honours = | horses = }} '''Georges Stern''' (1882 ‚Äì October 1928), nicknamed "'''The King of the Derbies"'''and "'''King of the Jockeys'''", was a French jockey.<ref name="jewishsports1">{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishsports.net/BioPages/GeorgesStern.htm |title=Georges Stern |publisher=Jewishsports.net |date= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref> He rode in both England and France.<ref name="jewishsports1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=x28uAAAAIBAJ&sjid=p9kFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3701,718917&dq=derby+george-stern&hl=en |title=French Jockey Passes|work=Ottawa Citizen |date=29 October 1928 |author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
Stern, who was Jewish, was born in France to British parents, who were naturalized in France.<ref name="jewishsports1"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xcfef_d2es4C&pg=PA220&lpg=PA220&dq=%22Georges+Stern%22+jockey&source=bl&ots=YlX1rIcIV6&sig=NJEJSxhniMm_zr8vYa4-5T65bgA&hl=en&ei=cR2kTrG7NYfV0QG5ieC1BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Big Book of Jewish Sports Heroes: An Illustrated Compendium of Sports History and The 150 Greatest Jewish Sports Stars|author=Peter S. Horvitz |publisher= |year= 2007|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t7RSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YzcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3236,4254561&dq=derby+george-stern&hl=en |title=English Jockey a Thing of the Past |work=The Morning Leader |date= 26 June 1913|author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
In 1904, he won the Grand Prix, the [[French Derby]] (riding Ajax), the [[French Oaks]] (Profane), the Austrian Derby (Con Amore), the [[German Derby]] (Con Amore), and the Baden Baden Prix (Caius).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=TO19050401.2.23 |title=CAP and JACKET |work=Observer |date=1 April 1905 |author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
In 1908 he won the French Derby, the Austrian Derby, and the German Derby, and finished second in the Belgian Derby.<ref name="jewishsports1"/><ref name="google1">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAq4TGQsWwwC&pg=PA164&dq=derby+%22Georges+Stern%22&hl=en&ei=ER6kTr3zH6Hl0QHXu-jzDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=derby%20%22Georges%20Stern%22&f=false |title=Day by day in Jewish sports history |author=Bob Wechsler |publisher= KTAV Publishing House, Inc.|year= 2008|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref>
In 1898, at 17 years of age, in [[Colombes]] Stern won his first race riding Finlas, a horse owned and trained by his father.<ref name="jewishsports1"/> In 1900, he won the debut [[Grand Prix de Deauville]], riding Amedee.<ref name="jewishsports1"/> That year, with 91 wins he ranked as the best jockey in the world.<ref name="jewishsports1"/> He won the Deauville again in 1901 (riding [[Jacobite (horse)|Jacobite]]), 1902 ([[Maximum (horse)|Maximum]]), and 1909 ([[Biniou]]).<ref name="jewishsports1"/>
He won the 1911 [[Epsom Derby]] (riding [[Sunstar]]).<ref name="jewishsports1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Fu49AAAAIBAJ&sjid=yUgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1837,2390882&dq=derby+george-stern&hl=en |title=Lame Excuses Aren't Needed |work=The Glasgow Herald |date= 11 June 1980|author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ez1MAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OioDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2913,5423097&dq=derby+george-stern&hl=en |title=The Winner of the Epsom Derby |work=The Toronto World |date= 4 June 1911|author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WMRSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ajcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3585,4147722&dq=derby+george-stern&hl=en |title=The Favorite Won |work=The Morning Leader |date= 2 June 1911|author= |accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref> He was a six-time winner of the [[Prix du Jockey Club]]‚Äôs French Derby‚Äîin 1901 ([[Saxon (French horse)|Saxon]]), 1904 ([[Ajax (horse)|Ajax]]), 1908 ([[Quintette (horse)|Quintette]]), 1913 (Dagor), 1914 ([[Sardanapale]]), and 1922 ([[Ramus (horse)|Ramus]]).<ref name="jewishsports1"/> He won the [[Grand Prix de Paris]] in 1904 (Ajax), 1913 (Bruleur), 1914 ([[Sardanapale]]), and 1922 (Ramus).<ref name="jewishsports1"/><ref name="google1"/>
He retired in 1926.<ref name="jewishsports1"/> In his career, he had over 1,000 victories.<ref name="jewishsports1"/> He died at the age of 48, in November 1928 in France.<ref name="jewishsports1"/>
In 1993, he was elected a member of the [[International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame]].<ref name="jewishsports1"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stern, Georges}} [[Category:French jockeys]] [[Category:1882 births]] [[Category:1928 deaths]] [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:Jewish sportspeople]]

#REDIRECT [[Ada regulon]] {{R from other capitalisation}}

'''Hal H. Carleton''' was an Australian writer. He was a friend of film director [[Ken G. Hall]] and was part of Hall's comedy writing team at [[Cinesound Productions]] in the late 1930s. He also wrote novels.<ref>Phil Taylor, 'Ken G. Hall', ''Cinema Papers'', January 1974 p 85</ref>
==Select Credits== *''[[The Spirit of Gallipoli]]'' (1928) - screenplay *''[[Let George Do It (1938 film)|Let George Do It]]'' (1938) - original story *''[[Dad and Dave Come to Town]]'' (1938) - uncredited contribution to screenplay *''Murder Every 28 Days!'' - novella *''They're Coming to Get Me'' - novella
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://0-austlit.edu.au.library.sl.nsw.gov.au/run?ex=ShowAgent&agentId=A-)4 Hal Carleton] at [[AustLit]] (subscription required) *[http://colsearch.nfsa.gov.au/nfsa/search/summary/summary.w3p;adv=;group=;groupequals=;page=0;parentid=;query=Person%3A%22%2FPerson%2Fkey%2F52721-1%22;querytype=;resCount=10 Hal Carleton] at [[National Film and Sound Archive]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carleton, Hal}} [[Category:Australian writers]]

{{Infobox song | name = Baby Goodbye | cover = Fridayhillbabygoodbye.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Friday Hill]] | album = [[Times Like These (Friday Hill album)|Times Like These]] | B-side = Running Away | released = 10 October 2005 | format = [[CD single]], [[Music download|digital download]] | recorded = 2005 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = | label = [[Polydor Records]] | writer = Wilkins / Hubert / Eyre | producer = | prev_title = [[Here 4 One]] | prev_year = 2004 | next_title = [[One More Night Alone]] | next_year = 2006 }} "'''Baby Goodbye'''" is a song by pop trio [[Blazin' Squad|Friday Hill]], released as the lead single from their debut studio album, ''[[Times Like These (Friday Hill album)|Times Like These]]''. Despite being released under the name Friday Hill, the song is included as part of Blazin' Squad's discography. The song also features on [[Now That's What I Call Music! 62 (UK series)|Now 62]], which was released on 21 November 2005. ==Background== Following the split of ten-piece hip-hop group [[Blazin' Squad]], band members Stryder, Flava and Kenzie were offered a record deal by Polydor records, to form as a trio and record an album together. The trio originally expressed the intention to continue performing as Blazin' Squad, however, due to licensing rights, the name was not available. As such, they decided to form under the name Friday Hill, which was created based around the trio's hometown of Chingford. The song is very much a departure from Blazin' Squad's style of music, but was still successful commercially. Released on 10 October 2005, the single peaked at number 5 on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. ==Music video== The music video for "Baby Goodbye" premiered in September 2005, at a total length of three minutes and thirty-nine seconds.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W29uegA8ng4 The video was filmed entirely in black and white, and features shots of the band in and around a country house, with images of a girl they are singing to intertwinned. The band's performance in very casual costumes was criticised, however, the video was still given strong airplay. ==Track listing== * '''Digital EP''' # "Baby Goodbye" (Radio Edit) - 3:39 # "Running Away" (Studio Demo) - 3:05 # "Baby Goodbye" (Main Version with rap) - 4:03 # "Baby Goodbye" (Acapella) - 3:50 * '''UK CD #1''' # "Baby Goodbye" (Radio Edit) - 3:39 # "Running Away" (Studio Demo) - 3:05 * '''UK CD #2''' # "Baby Goodbye" (Radio Edit) - 3:39 # "Baby Goodbye" (Main Version with rap) - 4:03 # "Baby Goodbye" (Acapella) - 3:50 # "Baby Goodbye" (CD-Rom Video) - 3:39 ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable" ! Chart (2005) ! Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Ireland|8|year=2005|week=41}} |- {{singlechart|UK|5|date=2005-10-17}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Blazin' Squad}} ==External links== * [http://www.allthelyrics.com/lyrics/friday_hill/baby_goodbye-lyrics-436108.html baby goodbye friday hill lyrics] [[Category:2005 singles]] [[Category:Blazin' Squad songs]] [[Category:2005 songs]] [[Category:Polydor Records singles]]

{{Redirect|The Stallions|other uses|Stallion (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{short description|Filipino association football club based in Bi√±an, Laguna}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = '''Stallion Laguna''' | image = Stallion Laguna FC Logo.png | image_size = 250px | fullname = Stallion Laguna Football Club | nickname = The Stallions | short name = STA | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2002}} | ground = [[Bi√±an Football Stadium]] | capacity = 2,580 | coordinates = | owntitle = | owner = [[Ricardo Penson]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/367769/ricardo-penson-seeks-to-represent-those-left-out |title=Ricardo Penson seeks to represent those left out f|first=Jerome |last=Aning |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=2013-03-03 |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> | chrtitle = | chairman = | mgrtitle = Head coach | manager = [[Ernest Nierras]] | league = [[Philippines Football League]] | season = [[2019 Philippines Football League|2019]] | position = To be determined | current = 2019 Stallion Laguna F.C. season | website = http://stallionfcphil.com/| | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = _pink stripes | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = FF0F5C | body1 = FF0F5C | rightarm1 = FF0F5C | shorts1 = 000000 | socks1 = FFFFFF| | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2 = 584EEE | body2 = 584EEE | rightarm2 = 584EEE | shorts2 = FFFFFF | socks2 = FFFFFF| | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so3 = | leftarm3 = 9B246B | body3 = 9B246B | rightarm3 = 9B246B | shorts3 = 0000FF | socks3 = ED1C24 | American = true }}
'''Stallion Laguna Football Club''' is a [[Philippines|Filipino]] professional association [[Football team|football club]] based in [[Bi√±an, Laguna]] that competes in the [[Philippines Football League]], the top division of Filipino football.
In 2002, the club was founded as Stallion Football Club. The club competed in the Metro Manila-based [[United Football League (Philippines)|United Football League]], earning promotion to Division 1 after finishing as runners-up in the [[2011 United Football League (Philippines)|2011 season]]. The club proceeded to compete in the UFL Division 1 from 2012 to 2016, winning one [[United Football League (Philippines)|United Football League]] title and one [[2012 UFL Cup|UFL Cup]], both in the [[2013 United Football League (Philippines)|2012‚Äì2013 UFL season]].
Originally based in [[Barotac Nuevo, Iloilo]], the club moved to the [[Bi√±an Football Stadium]] in [[Bi√±an, Laguna]] in 2016, when the club formally submitted its application to join the Philippines Football League, the first true national football league in the [[Philippines]].<ref>http://www.panaynews.net/ufl-teams-moving-to-pfl/</ref> Stallion Laguna also used 4,500-capacity [[McKinley Hill Stadium]] for some home games.
==History== In 2002, a group of football enthusiasts from [[Barotac Nuevo, Iloilo]] thought of establishing a club that would regularly compete in football tournaments held in the town. The name of the club was conceptualized during a [[Drinking culture#Social drinking|drinking session]] where most of the group were drinking [[Red Horse Beer|Red Horse Stallion Beer]]. Realizing that the town's folklore hero is Tamasak, a pure white Stallion known for its strength, the group decided to use the name Stallion Football Club. <ref>{{cite news |url=http://fcstallion.blogspot.com/p/stallion-fc-of-barotac-nuevo-brief.html |title=Stallion FC of Barotac Nuevo Brief History |author=Catalan, Denrei |work= |publisher=Stallion Football Club official website |date= |accessdate=30 September 2012 }}</ref>
The club made its debut in the Barotac Nuevo Football Club (BNFC) Seven-a-Side Football Tournament. Stallion continued to participate in numerous major and minor football competitions throughout the years, including the Siniki Football Festival and other tournaments in [[Cebu]], [[Boracay]], [[Subic, Zambales|Subic]], [[Metro Manila]] and [[Capiz]].
It has also been competing in major football tournaments in the country, most recently in the [[2011 PFF National Men's Club Championship|2011 PFF-Smart Club Championships]].<ref>{{cite news |title=PFF-Smart Club kicks off August 9 |work=The Visayan Daily Star |date=3 August 2011 |url=http://www.visayandailystar.com/2011/August/03/sportnews3.htm |accessdate=6 November 2011}}</ref> In this tournament, the club lost to San Beda FC in the quarterfinals, 2‚Äì1.<ref>{{cite news |title=San Beda slips past Stallions and into PFF-SMART Club finals |work=interaksyon.com |date=18 August 2011 |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/san-beda-slips-past-stallions-and-into-pff-smart-club-finals |accessdate=6 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccercentral.ph/news/pff-smart-san-beda-fc-advances-finals |title=PFF-Smart: San Beda FC Advances to the Finals |author=de Guzman, Mikhail |publisher=Soccer Central Philippines |date=18 August 2011|accessdate=6 November 2011 }}</ref>
===2010‚Äì11: Promotion to UFL Division 1=== Stallion FC finished as one of the top three teams in the [[United Football League (Philippines)#Division 2|UFL Division 2]] during the [[2011 United Football League (Philippines)|2011 United Football League]] season. This automatically earned the club a [[Promotion and relegation|promotion]] to the UFL Division 1 along with [[Manila Nomads F.C.|Manila Nomads]] and [[Pasargad F.C.|Pasargad]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sports.inquirer.net/29465/ufl-promotes-three-teams-to-first-division |title=UFL promotes three teams to first division |author=Tupas, Cedelf |work=inquirer.net |publisher=The Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=18 December 2011 |accessdate=31 December 2011 }}</ref>
===2011‚Äì12: Debut in first division=== At the start of the [[2012 United Football League (Philippines)|2012 United Football League]] season, in the club's first match in the [[United Football League (Philippines)#Division 1|UFL Division 1]], Stallion defeated [[Philippine Navy F.C.|Philippine Navy]], 6‚Äì0. In their next match, the team defeated the [[2011 UFL Cup]] and then current league champions [[Philippine Air Force F.C.|Philippine Air Force]], 4‚Äì1. In addition, the club also scored a 3‚Äì2 win against eventual [[2012 United Football League (Philippines)|2012 season]] champions [[Global FC]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/244468/sports/football/ufl-big-four-still-favorites-to-win-league-title |title=UFL: Big Four still favorites to win league title |author=Moore, Roy |work= |publisher=GMA News Online |date=13 January 2012 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref>
To close the season, Stallion defeated [[Philippine Army F.C.|Philippine Army]] in their last couple of games. With these two wins, the club secured the fourth spot of the top division.<ref>[http://www.uflphilippines.com.ph/news-view/1340325680660/kaya-keeps-title-hopes-alive-stallion-seals-4th.html Kaya keeps title hopes alive; Stallion seals 4th] United Football League. Retrieved 28 June 2012</ref>
===2012‚Äì13: New signings and affiliate team=== In preparation for the [[2013 United Football League (Philippines)|2013 season]], aside from sharing its [[coaching staff]] with an affiliate Sta. Lucia-owned club, Stallion signed footballers Rhante Bayquin and Won Hyung Lee to beef up their lineup for the [[2012 UFL Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bleachersbrew.blogspot.com/2012/09/ufl-preview-call-to-arms-part-1.html |title=UFL Preview: A call to arms Part 1 |author=Olivares, Rick |work= |publisher=Bleachers' Brew Online |date=21 September 2012 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> In addition, the club also got the services of Spanish [[midfielder]] Rufino Familiar Sanchez and [[Defender (association football)|defender]] Joaquin Canas Garcia from [[Internacional de Madrid CF]], an association football club from [[Moraleja de Enmedio]] in [[Community of Madrid]], Spain that plays in the [[Tercera Divisi√≥n Groups 1-9|Tercera Divisi√≥n]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ph.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/thepassionatefan/stallion-fc-means-business-signings-affiliate-team-143508029.html |title=Stallion FC means business with new signings and affiliate team |author=Guerrero, Bob |work= |publisher=Yahoo! Philippines Sports |date=14 September 2012 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref>
In August 2012, Stallion announced that it has signed [[Filipino people|Filipino]] international player and [[Philippines national under-23 football team]] captain [[Jason de Jong]] for the upcoming season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-signs-jason-de-jong-spanish-players-to-boost-ufl-campaign |title=Stallion signs Jason de Jong, Spanish players to boost UFL campaign |author=Decena, Karl |work=InterAKTV.ph |publisher=Associated Broadcasting Company (TV5) |date=17 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818233136/http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-signs-jason-de-jong-spanish-players-to-boost-ufl-campaign |archivedate=18 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> De Jong, who also represents the [[Philippines national football team]] in the international level, was initially offered to play for Stallion in March 2012, but then he was offered a trial with [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]]. Eventually, due to financial constraints, the [[Scottish Football League First Division|Scottish First Division]] side was forced to let De Jong go, which enabled Stallion to finally sign him to a contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.philstar.com/sportsarticle.aspx?articleid=786278&publicationsubcategoryid=69 |title=De Jong signs up with Scottish League club |author=Leyba, Olmin |work=The Philippine Star |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=31 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ayrshirepost.net/ayrshire-sport/ayrshire-football/ayr-utd-fc/2012/03/23/ayr-united-s-injury-luck-clears-for-crunch-visit-of-morton-102545-30590608/|title=Ayr United's injury luck clears for crunch visit of Morton|last=Wilson|first=Mike|work=Ayrshire Post|date=23 March 2012|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref>
====UFL Cup champions==== {{football squad on pitch|align=right |GK =[[Wilson Mu√±oz|'''Mu√±oz ''']] |RB ='''Italia''' |RCB=[[Joaqu√≠n Ca√±as|'''Ca√±as''']] |LCB='''Hugo''' |LB =[[Pi Yong-Jae|'''Pi''']] |AM =[[Ruben Doctora|'''Doctora (C)''']] |RCM='''[[Kim Hyo-Il]]''' |LCM=[[Jason de Jong|'''de Jong''']] |LM =[[Joo Young Lee|'''Lee''']] |RM =[[Won Hyung Lee|'''Hyung''']] |CF =[[Rufo S√°nchez|'''Rufo''']] |caption=[[2012 UFL Cup]] final starting lineup }} The club started in the group stages and topped [[2012 UFL Cup#Group D|Group D]] with 9 points (3 wins, 1 loss) to qualify in the knockout stage. In the quarterfinals of the cup's [[2012 UFL Cup#Knockout stage|knockout stage]], Stallion defeated General Trias FC on penalty shoot out with 5‚Äì4 result. In the [[2012 UFL Cup#Semi-finals|semi-finals]], the club edged [[Green Archers United F.C.|Green Archers United]] with a scoreline of 3‚Äì1, booking them for the finals.
On 17 December 2012, Stallion FC defeated [[Global FC]] on the [[2012 UFL Cup#Final|finals]] of the UFL Cup in the [[Rizal Memorial Stadium]], Manila with a score of 2‚Äì1, getting the cup title and its first UFL crown. Team captain [[Ruben Doctora]] and Spanish striker [[Rufo S√°nchez]] scored one goal apiece to upset previous league champions Global.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-wins-ufl-cup-in-upset-over-global |title=Stallion wins UFL Cup in upset over Global |author=Decena, Karl |work=InterAKTV.ph |publisher=Associated Broadcasting Company (TV5) |date=17 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121219070148/http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-wins-ufl-cup-in-upset-over-global |archivedate=19 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Doctora won the [[2012 UFL Cup#Awards|Golden Ball]] award, the tournament's equivalent to the [[Most Valuable Player]] award, while Wilson Mu√±oz bagged the Golden Glove trophy as the best goalkeeper in the competition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-players-notch-top-ufl-cup-awards |title=Stallion players notch top UFL Cup awards |author=Decena, Karl |work=InterAKTV.ph |publisher=Associated Broadcasting Company (TV5) |date=17 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121219194557/http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/stallion-players-notch-top-ufl-cup-awards |archivedate=19 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====PFF Championship early exit==== To prepare for the second season of the [[PFF National Men's Club Championship]], Stallion enlisted the services of American soccer midfielder Jeremy Taylor Hohn and [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] Cyrus Andre Mohseni, who was part of the under-18 team of the [[U.S. Soccer Development Academy]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.watchmendaily.com/sports/pff-smart-club-tilt-azkals-booters-to-boost-ceres-stallion-faceoff/ |title=PFF-SMART CLUB TILT Azkals booters to boost Ceres-Stallion faceoff |author=Galunan, Jerome |work= |publisher=The Watchmen Daily Journal |date=12 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://ussda.demosphere.com/teams/37416866/37418057-37416960/31884492.html |title=Player profile: Cyrus Andre Mohseni |author= |work=U.S. Soccer Development Academy |publisher=Demosphere International, Inc. |date= }}</ref>
On 13 January 2013, [[Negros Occidental]]-based club [[Ceres F.C.|Ceres FC]] pulled a stunning 1‚Äì0 upset over Stallion FC, eliminating the [[2012 UFL Cup]] champions from the [[2013 PFF National Men's Club Championship]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/ceres-shocks-ufl-cup-champ-stallion-in-pff-nationals-global-pasargad-advance |title=Ceres shocks UFL Cup champ Stallion in PFF nationals; Global, Pasargad advance |author=Decena, Karl |work=InterAKTV.ph |publisher=Associated Broadcasting Company (TV5) |date=13 January 2013}}</ref>
====UFL Division 1 campaign==== After a disappointing run in the [[2013 PFF National Men's Club Championship]], Stallion signed several foreign football players to bolster its lineup including Colombian-born American [[Forward (association football)|forward]] [[Diego Barrera]], Argentinian [[Midfielder#Winger|midfielder]] Matthias Bonvehi, Japanese midfielder Yuuri Ishizuka, [[Japanese Brazilian|Brazilian-Japanese]] midfielder [[Daniel Matsunaga]], and Australian [[Defender (association football)|defender]] Jesse Martindale.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ph.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/thepassionatefan/ufl-stallion-drops-sparks-archers-overcome-nomads-chieffy-234744582.html |title=UFL: Stallion drops Sparks, Archers overcome Nomads with late Chieffy goal |author=Guerrero, Bob |work= |publisher=Yahoo! Sports Philippines |date=10 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uflphilippines.com.ph/cup/newscup-view/1363344169464/breaking-down-stallions-win-over-pachanga-diliman.html |title=Breaking down Stallion's win over Pachanga-Diliman |author= |work= |publisher=United Football League Philippines |date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://filipinofootball.blogspot.com/2013/01/sta-lucia-stallion-fc-2013-team-roster.html |title=Sta Lucia Stallion FC ‚Äì 2013 team roster for UFL |author= |work= |publisher=Filipino Football: Philippine Football News website |date=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spin.ph/sports/football/stars-earn-stripes/daniel-matsunaga-shows-hes-more-than-just-a-pretty-face-in-ufls-top-flight |title=Daniel Matsunaga shows he's more than just a pretty face in UFL's top flight |author=Sacamos, Karlo |work= |publisher=Sports Interactive Network Philippines |date=21 February 2013}}</ref> In addition, several players from local clubs transferred to Stallion such as Brazilian [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] Guilherme Hasegawa from [[Team Socceroo F.C.|Team Socceroo FC]] and [[Midfielder#Winger|midfielder]] Shirmar Felongco from [[Ceres F.C.|Ceres FC]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ph.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/thepassionatefan/ufl-stallion-global-win-pachanga-boss-alleges-assistant-033703505.html |title=UFL: Stallion, Global win, Pachanga boss alleges assistant ref is racist |author=Guerrero, Bob |work= |publisher=Yahoo! Sports Philippines |date=15 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spin.ph/sports/football/news/rampaging-stallions-four-star-performance-sends-loyola-reeling-v02 |title=Rampaging Stallion's four-star performance sends Loyola reeling |author=Sacamos, Karlo |work= |publisher=Sports Interactive Network Philippines |date=9 April 2013}}</ref>
On 13 June 2013, Stallion clinched the [[United Football League (Philippines)#Division 1|Division 1]] championship of the [[2013 United Football League (Philippines)|2013 United Football League]] after [[Kaya F.C.|Kaya]] came away with a 3‚Äì2 victory against [[Global F.C.|Global]] at the Emperador Stadium in Mckinley Hill, [[Taguig]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/global-falters-against-kaya-hands-stallion-ufl-title |title=Global falters against Kaya, hands Stallion UFL title |author=Karl Decena |work=http://www.interaksyon.com/ |publisher=www.interaksyon.com/ |date=13 June 2013 |accessdate=14 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924080628/http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/global-falters-against-kaya-hands-stallion-ufl-title |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Philippines Football League=== Stallion FC were set to participate at the [[2017 Philippines Football League|inaugural season]] of the [[Philippines Football League]] (PFL) in 2017. They designated [[Bi√±an Football Stadium]] as their home turf and by mid-January 2017 already started pre-season training and tryouts in the venue. The club renamed themselves as Stallion Laguna FC as part of their participation in the PFL.<ref name="preparesPFL">{{cite news|last1=Biantan|first1=Jack|title=Stallions FC Laguna prepares for Philippine Football League|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cagayan-de-oro/sports/2017/01/17/stallions-fc-laguna-prepares-philippine-football-league-520527|accessdate=17 January 2017|work=Sun Star|date=17 January 2017}}</ref>
===Philippine Premier League=== In 2019, Stallion Laguna joined the [[Philippine Premier League]] (PPL), a league which replaced the PFL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/article/120868/|title=Stallions FC Laguna prepares for Philippine Football League|first=Jack|last=Biantan|date=17 January 2017|website=Sunstar|accessdate=26 December 2018}}</ref> However they along with [[United Makati F.C.|United Makati]] withdrew from the league on April 26, 2019, a day before the first match day of the league citing concerns regarding what the Stallion management see as a lack of professionalism and transparency regarding the league's management.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Saldajeno |first1=Ivan Stewart |title=Stallion Laguna, Global Makati withdraw from PPL |url=https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1068344 |accessdate=27 April 2019 |agency=Philippine News Agency |date=27 April 2019}}</ref>
==Youth== Stallion Laguna runs a youth football academy known as the Stallion Youth Academy. Starting the 2019 season the academy would be merging with the Makati Football Club (MFC) with the existing academy of the club to be renamed as the Stallion MFC Youth Academy. MFC was managed by Stallion former player Selu Lozano who would be rejoining the club as a player and corporate manager for the 2019 season.<ref name="exDavao">{{cite news |last1=Saldajeno |first1=Ivan Stewart |title=Deyto headlines Laguna's preseason pickups |url=https://www.dugout.ph/2019/01/deyto-headlines-lagunas-pickups.html |accessdate=30 January 2019 |agency=Dugout Philippines |date=30 January 2019}}</ref>

===Foreign players=== In the [[Philippine Premier League]], there can be at least four non-Filipino nationals in a team as long as they are registered. Foreign players who have acquired [[permanent residency]] can be registered as locals.

[[Manchester Rugby Club|Manchester Football Club]]

[[Cheshire Rugby Football Union|Cheshire]]
[[Lancashire County Rugby Football Union|Lancashire]]
[[North of England Rugby Union side|North of England]] | occupation = | school = | university = }} '''Hugh Campbell Rowley''' (March 1854 ‚Äì after 1882) was an English [[rugby union]] footballer of the 1870s and 1880s. He played at representative level for [[England national rugby union team|England]] from 1879 to 1882, and at club level for [[Bowdon and Lymm Club]], and [[Manchester Rugby Club]], as a [[Rugby union positions#Forwards|forward]]. ==Early life== Rowley was born in [[Chorlton-on-Medlock]]. ==Rugby union career== Rowley was originally a member of the Bowdon and Lymm Club, and was selected from this club to represent the county of Cheshire in the first match between Cheshire and Lancashire on 24 February 1877. He had the distinction of scoring the first try in that match, and the first point of importance against Lancashire. Ironically, Rowley then went on to play in and for Lancashire, transferring to the Manchester Football Club, and representing Lancashire in 1879 for whom he played over a number of years. He was also selected to play in several North v. South matches, once the pinnacle of domestic rugby competition. Rowley made his international debut for [[England national rugby union team|England]] on 10 March 1879 in the match against [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] match at [[Raeburn Place|Edinburgh]]. He played eight more times for England, (vs Scotland in 1879-80-81-82; vs Ireland, 1879-80-81-82; and Wales, 1881.) Of the nine matches he played for his national side the team won five times, lost once, and drew three times. He played his final match for England on 4 March 1882 against [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] at [[Whalley Range, Manchester]]. He was described in a contemporary account as a celebrated player and ''"one of the best all-round men who ever played the Rugby game."'' The account went on to say ''"Campbell Rowley was one of the most useful of football players, very strong and fast, was never done with, could play any position in the field equally well, and had his whole heart in the game."''Francis Marshall. ''Football; the Rugby union game'', p403, 1892 ==Later life== Rowley later moved to [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rowley, Hugh}} [[Category:1854 births]] [[Category:English rugby union players]] [[Category:England international rugby union players]] [[Category:Rugby union forwards]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Lancashire County RFU players]] {{England-rugbyunion-bio-stub}}

'''[[Calabozos]]''' is a [[Holocene]] [[caldera]] in the [[Maule Region]] in central [[Chile]]. Part of the Chilean [[Andes]]' volcanic segment, it is considered a member of the [[Andean Volcanic Belt#Southern Volcanic Zone|Southern Volcanic Zone]]. This most active section of the Andes runs through central and western Chile, and includes more than 70 of Chile's [[stratovolcano]]es and volcanic fields. Calabozos and the majority of the Andean volcanoes formed from the [[subduction]] of the oceanic [[Nazca Plate]] under the continental [[South American Plate|South American continental lithosphere]]. The caldera is in a transitional region between thick and thin lithosphere, and is probably supplied by a pool of [[Andesite|andesitic]] and [[Rhyolite|rhyolitic]] magma. It sits on a historic bed of volcanic and [[plutonic]] [[sedimentary rock]] that in turn sits on top of a layer of merged sedimentary and [[metamorphic rock]]. Calabozos is responsible for the huge Loma Seca [[Tuff]], a body of material 200 to 500 cubic kilometres (48 to 120 cu mi) in volume. It accumulated over at least three eruptive periods, beginning 800,000 years ago and lasting until 150,000 years ago. The caldera's dimensions are 26 by 14 kilometres (16 by 9 mi), and it has an [[elevation]] of 3,508 metres (11,509 ft). ([[Calabozos|'''more...''']]) Recently featured: [[Liberal Movement (Australia)|Liberal Movement]] ‚Äì [[Henry Wood]] ‚Äì [[Abdul Karim (the Munshi)|Abdul Karim]]

The Swamp Wallaby is found along the entire east coast of Australia. It was formerly found through to south-eastern [[South Australia]], but is now rare or absent from that region. It inhabits thick undergrowth in forests and woodlands, or shelter during the day in thick grass or ferns, emerging at night to feed. Photo: [[User:Benjamint444|Benjamint444]]

(0) | ru_ntupdate = 16 march 2019 }} '''Liam Williams''' (born 9 April 1991) is a Welsh international union player currently playing for [[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]]. He previously played for [[Scarlets]], [[Llanelli RFC|Llanelli]] and local club [[Waunarlwydd RFC]] either at fullback or wing. Fullback is his preferred position.[https://archive.is/20120913044447/http://www.llanellirugby.com/Personnel.aspx?pr=212284] Williams is known for his unusual running style and his fearless style of play.{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-news/making-liam-williams-wales-star-11493437|title=The making of Liam Williams as Wales star wins over NZ critics|last=Griffiths|first=Gareth|date=2016-06-19|newspaper=Walesonline.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-26}} ==Club career== A school boy developed by the local [[Waunarlwydd RFC]] club, he was not picked up by any of the Welsh regional professional academies, and hence aged 16 started working as a trainee [[scaffolding|scaffolder]] at [[Port Talbot Steelworks]], whilst continuing to play for Waunarlwydd.https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-news/awesome-picture-wales-rugby-stars-15441356 Aged 20 he was signed by [[Scarlets]], being developed for his first year in 2010-11 at [[Llanelli RFC]]. In 2017, it was announced Williams would be joining [[Aviva Premiership]] side [[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]] in England on a three-year contract from the 2017‚Äì18 season.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/jan/09/wales-rugby-union-international-liam-williams-three-year-deal-saracens|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|title=Saracens sign Wales and Scarlets utility back Liam Williams|date=9 February 2017|accessdate=18 February 2017}} In part the decision was based on his relationship with London-based Welsh model Sophie Harries, whom he had been dating since 2015.https://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/showbiz/who-rugby-star-liam-williams-12214182 ==International== In November 2011, Williams was named in the senior [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] training squad for the match versus Australia on 3 December 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/15809004|title=Warren Gatland gambles on fitness doubts for Australia Test|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 October 2017}} He made his debut for Wales against the [[Barbarian F.C.|Barbarians]] on 2 June 2012 at the [[Millennium Stadium]]. He scored his first international try on 15 March 2014 versus [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] and was named Man of the Match. Williams was selected for the British and Irish Lions in 2017 to tour to New Zealand. Williams was yellow carded in his first match on tour which was a loss against the Blues, but silenced critics with a standout performance against the Chiefs. Williams started in every match of the test series against the All Blacks at fullback instead of his usual position for club and county, on the wing. Williams also set up what was arguably the best try of the series in the first half of the first test.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20130428203315/http://www.scarlets.co.uk/eng/rugby/people.php?player=96023&includeref=dynamic Scarlets profile] * {{scrum|136556}} {{Saracens squad}} {{British and Irish Lions 2017}} {{Wales Squad 2015 Rugby World Cup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Williams, Liam}} [[Category:1991 births]] [[Category:British and Irish Lions rugby union players from Wales]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rugby union players from Swansea]] [[Category:Scarlets players]] [[Category:Wales international rugby union players]]

[[User:MikeWazowski|MikeWazowski]] ([[User talk:MikeWazowski|talk]]) 14:40, 23 October 2011 (UTC) I kindly ask you NOT to delete this article. We will provide additional references as needed. Thanks --[[Special:Contributions/212.29.234.47|212.29.234.47]] ([[User talk:212.29.234.47|talk]]) 15:06, 23 October 2011 (UTC)‚Äî [[Special:Contributions/212.29.234.47|212.29.234.47]] ([[User talk:212.29.234.47|talk]]) has made [[Wikipedia:Single-purpose account|few or no other edits]] outside this topic. *'''Comment''' The previously-deleted article from yesterday was a far more substantial article than this iteration, which barely rises above a screen-shot. It - and the arguments by its creator(s) on its Talk page - contained at least the beginning of an arguable notability. [[User:AllyD|AllyD]] ([[User talk:AllyD|talk]]) 15:51, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete''' Web searches turn up references to other IT products of the same name (from Hitachi and a CRM vendor of that name) but nothing substantial and independent relating to this data conversion/cleansing product from Target Data. [[User:AllyD|AllyD]] ([[User talk:AllyD|talk]]) 16:55, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Software|list of Software-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:AllyD|AllyD]] ([[User talk:AllyD|talk]]) 19:04, 23 October 2011 (UTC) * '''Delete''' Not notable of a software. [[User:Grim Littlez|KING GRIM LOL YO WHATS UP]] ([[User talk:Grim Littlez|talk]]) 21:17, 23 October 2011 (UTC) * '''Delete'''. Not notable. No reliable, unbiased, third-party sources. Author ({{user|Vullik}}) clearly has a [[WP:COI|conflict-of-interest]]. ‚Äî[[User:DragonHawk|DragonHawk]] ([[User talk:DragonHawk|talk]]|[[Special:Contributions/DragonHawk|hist]]) 06:44, 25 October 2011 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Yamada Nobumichi
Â±±Áî∞ ‰ø°ÈÅì | image = Yamada Nobumichi.jpg | alt = | caption = Yamada Nobumichi | birth_date = {{Birth date|1833|12|13}} | birth_place = [[Kumamoto, Kumamoto|Kumamoto]], [[Higo Province]], Japan | death_date = {{Death date and age|1900|03|11|1833|12|13}} | death_place = | nationality = Japanese | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = politician, cabinet minister }} {{Japanese name|Yamada}} {{nihongo|'''Yamada Nobumichi'''|Â±±Áî∞ ‰ø°ÈÅì||extra=13 December 1833 – 11 March 1900}} was a statesman in early [[Meiji period]] [[Japan]]. ==Biography== Yamada was born in [[Kumamoto Domain]], [[Higo Province]] (present-day [[Kumamoto Prefecture]]). He was active in the ''[[Sonn≈ç j≈çi]]'' movement, relocated to [[Satsuma Domain]] during the [[Bakumatsu period]]. Captured by security forces of the [[Tokugawa shogunate]] in 1863, he was sentenced to five years in prison. After the [[Meiji restoration]], Yamada was recruited into the new [[Meiji government]] and was assigned as governor of the short-lived Esashi Prefecture (now part of [[Akita Prefecture|Akita]] and [[Iwate Prefecture]]s in 1871. Although Yamada was sympathetic to the grievances of the ex-[[samurai]] class and personally acquainted with many of the leaders of the [[Shinp≈´ren Rebellion]] in his native Kumamoto, he remained loyal to the Meiji government throughout the uprising. He was rewarded with the governorships of [[Shimane Prefecture]] (1881‚Äì1888), [[Fukushima Prefecture]] (1888‚Äì1891), [[Osaka Prefecture]] (1891‚Äì1895) and [[Kyoto Prefecture]] (1895‚Äì1897). On June 5, 1896 he was elevated to the rank of [[baron]] (''danshaku'') in the ''[[kazoku]] '' peerage system. Yamada was selected [[Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce|Minister of Agriculture & Commerce]] in the second [[Matsukata Masayoshi]] cabinet from 1897-1898. He subsequently served as chairman of the [[Board of Audit (Japan)|Board of Audit]] to his death in 1900. His grave is at the [[Aoyama Cemetery]] in Tokyo. {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before=[[Okuma Shigenobu]] | title=[[Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce|Minister of Agriculture & Commerce]] | years=Nov 1897 ‚Äì Jan 1898| after=[[It≈ç Miyoji]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yamada, Nobumichi}} [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1900 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kumamoto Prefecture]] [[Category:Kazoku]] [[Category:People of Meiji-period Japan]] [[Category:Government ministers of Japan]] [[Category:Governors of Japanese prefectures]] [[Category:Governors of Osaka]] [[Category:Governors of Kyoto Prefecture]]

page.title: List of anthologies of Greek epigrams

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{citation style|date=July 2014}} {{more footnotes|date=July 2014}} }}
Collections of Greek inscriptions initially started from the 3rd century BC and continued with collections of [[epigram]]s and short poems, which after the 1st century AD were called Anthologies. These '''anthologies of Greek epigrams''' were enlarged with additions of earlier collections, culminating in what is called today "[[Greek Anthology]]".
A list of certain of these works follows:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/2721.html | title=Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities | publisher=Little, Brown and company, Boston | work=Vol 1 | year=1867 | accessdate=September 3, 2011 | author=William Smith (editor) | pages=385‚Äì391 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022135503/http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/2721.html | archivedate=October 22, 2012 | df= }}, section entitled: Literary History of the Greek Anthology</ref><ref name="Mackail">{{cite web | url=http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/2378/pg2378.html | title=Select Epigrams from the Greek Anthology | publisher=Longmans, Green, and Co | year=1890 | accessdate=September 3, 2011 | author=J. W. Mackail | pages=Introduction, III}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lib.muohio.edu/multifacet/record/mu3ugb1986481 | title=The Greek anthology : from Meleager to Planudes | publisher=Oxford : Clarendon Press ; New York : Oxford University Press | year=1993 | accessdate=September 18, 2011 | author=Cameron, Alan | pages=405 | ISBN=0-19-814023-1}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=N7pEAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22Palatine%20Anthology%22&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q&f=false A manual of Greek literature:from the earliest authentic periods to the close of the Byzantine era], Charles Anthon, Harper, 1853, œÉŒµŒª. 81</ref>
*Attic inscriptions by [[Philochorus]], 3rd century BC *[[Soros (collection of epigrams)|Soros]], 3rd century BC, collection in which there were epigrams of [[Posidippus|Posidippus of Pella]]<ref name="KG">[https://books.google.com/books?id=shR3VJxlXZkC&lpg=PP1&hl=en&pg=PA7#v=onepage&q&f=false The New Posidippus: A Hellenistic Poetry Book], Kathryn J. Gutzwiller, Oxford University Press, 2005, œÉŒµŒª. 7, {{ISBN|0199267812}}, 9780199267811</ref> *[[Epigrammata]], 3rd century BC, collection of epigrams, attributed to Posidippus, of the same time as of Soros, but written later<ref name="KG"/> *[[On the inscriptions to be found in cities]], of [[Polemon of Athens]], 2nd century BC *About the offering in Delphi ({{lang|grc|Œ†ŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºêŒΩ ŒîŒµŒªœÜŒø·øñœÇ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ∏Œ∑ŒºŒ¨œÑœâŒΩ}}), of [[Alcetas the traveller]] *{{lang|grc|·ºòŒΩ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ ·ºÄŒΩŒ±Œ∏Œ∑ŒºŒ¨œÑœâŒΩ}}, of [[Menestor]] *[[Theban Epigrams]] ({{lang|grc|ŒòŒ∑Œ≤Œ±œäŒ∫·Ω∞ ·ºêœÄŒπŒ≥œÅŒ¨ŒºŒºŒ±œÑŒ±}}) of [[Aristodemus of Thebes]] *[[Peri epigrammaton]] ({{lang|grc|Œ†ŒµœÅ·Ω∂ ·ºêœÄŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±ŒºŒºŒ¨œÑœâŒΩ}}, "About epigrams") of [[Neoptolemus of Paros]] *[[Garland of Meleagros]] (Œ£œÑŒ≠œÜŒ±ŒΩŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒúŒµŒªŒµŒ¨Œ≥œÅŒøœÖ), of [[Meleager of Gadara]], the first use of the term Anthology for a collection of poems, about 1st century AD. *[[Garland of Philippus]] (Œ£œÑŒ≠œÜŒ±ŒΩŒøœÇ œÑŒø·ø¶ Œ¶ŒπŒªŒØœÄœÄŒøœÖ œÑŒø·ø¶ ŒòŒµœÉœÉŒ±ŒªŒøŒΩŒπŒ∫Œ≠œâœÇ), by [[Philippus of Thessalonica]], mid-1st century AD. *[[Sylloge Rufiniana]], supposed collection of epigrams of [[Rufinus (poet)|Rufinus]] found in Book V of the Palatine Anthology (or together with epigrams from other poets)<ref>[https://books.google.com/books/about/Die_sylloge_Rufiniana.html?id=q6DaHAAACAAJ&redir_esc=y Die sylloge Rufiniana], Markus Boas, 1920</ref><ref name=":0">[http://hw.oeaw.ac.at/buecher/files/Wiener_Byzantinistische_Studien/Byzantine_Poetry_from_Pisides_to_Geometres._Texts_and_Contexts._Volume_One/s083-128.pdf Chapter Three: Anthologies and Anthologists], Marc D. Lauxtermann, in Byzantine Poetry from Pisides to Geometres: Texts and Contexts volume One, page 104-105, 2003</ref> *[[Anthologion of epigrams]] about rivers, lakes, cliffs, mountains and mountaintops ({{lang|grc|·ºòœÄŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±ŒºŒºŒ¨œÑœâŒΩ ·ºÄŒΩŒ∏ŒøŒªœåŒ≥ŒπŒøŒΩ œÄŒµœÅ·Ω∂ œÄŒøœÑŒ±Œº·ø∂ŒΩ ŒªŒπŒºŒΩ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ∫œÅŒ∑ŒΩ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ΩÄœÅ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºÄŒ∫œÅœâœÅŒµŒπ·ø∂ŒΩ}}), [[Diogenianus]] *[[Musa Puerilis]] ({{lang|grc|ŒúŒø·ø¶œÉŒ± Œ†Œ±ŒπŒ¥ŒπŒ∫ŒÆ}}), anthology of [[Straton of Sardis]], 2nd century, with pederastic content *[[Pammetros]] ({{lang|grc|Œ†Œ¨ŒºŒºŒµœÑœÅŒøœÇ}}) of [[Diogenes La√´rtius]], 3rd century *The [[Sylloge of Pallada]], 5th-6th century<ref name=":0" /> *[[Cycle of New Epigrams]] ({{lang|grc|ŒöœçŒ∫ŒªŒøœÇ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ŒΩŒ≠œâŒΩ ·ºêœÄŒπŒ≥œÅŒ±ŒºŒºŒ¨œÑœâŒΩ}}), also known as "Cycle of Agathias" by [[Agathias]], 6th century *[[Anacreontea]], a collection originally attributed pseudepigraphically to Anacreon preserved in [[Anthologia Palatina]] (poems ranging from the 1st century BC to the 6th century AD) *[[Sylloge Parisina]] *[[Sylloge Euphemiana]] (about 890)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://hw.oeaw.ac.at/buecher/files/Wiener_Byzantinistische_Studien/Byzantine_Poetry_from_Pisides_to_Geometres._Texts_and_Contexts._Volume_One/s083-128.pdf | title=Byzantine Poetry from Pisides to Geometres | publisher=V√ñAW | work=Chapter Three: Anthologies and Anthologists | year=2003 | accessdate=September 10, 2011 | author=Lauxtermann, Marc D. | pages=83 | isbn=3-7001-3150-X}}</ref> *[[Syllogae minores]], a series of smaller collections from various sources, among which are Sylloge Parisina and Sylloge Euphemiana already mentioned above *''[[Anthology of Cephalas]]'' (contained the Garland of Meleagros, the Garland of Philippus and the Cycle of Agathias) by [[Constantine Cephalas]], 10th century (lost) ‚Äì the Palatine Anthology and the Anthology of Planudes are based on it, see below *''[[Palatine Anthology]]'' Anthologia Palatina (manuscript discovered in 1606 in the Palatine library at Heidelberg, which is considered to be based on the Anthology of Cephalas), approx. 980 *''[[Anthology of Planudes]]'' (Anthologia Graeca Planudea) [[Maximus Planudes]], 1299 (based mainly on apographon or on apographa of the Anthology of Cephalas) *''[[Greek Anthology]]'' (Anthologia Graeca): Term currently used for the collection of epigrams and poems of the Palatine and the Planudean Anthologies,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbqF8z2bq3sC&lpg=PA410&pg=PA410#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The Classical Tradition | publisher=Harvard University Press | year=2010 | accessdate=September 2, 2011 |author1=Anthony Grafton |author2=Glenn W. Most |author3=Salvatore Settis | pages=410}}</ref> as well as from other sources<ref>[http://www.lib.muohio.edu/multifacet/record/mu3ugb1986481 ''The Greek anthology : from Meleager to Planudes''] / Alan Cameron, Oxford : Clarendon Press ; New York : Oxford University Press, 1993, {{ISBN|0-19-814023-1}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Expand list|date=October 2011}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Poetry anthologies]] [[Category:Ancient Greek literature]] [[Category:Greek literature (post-classical)]] [[Category:Byzantine literature]] [[Category:Greek Anthology]]

revision.text:
[[File:Dirnanean.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Dirnanean Manor House]] [[File:Dirnanean Shepherd's House, Scotland.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Home Farm at Dirnanean]] '''Dirnanean House''' is part of a private, traditional Highland estate located near Enochdhu in Moulin parish, [[Blairgowrie and Rattray|Blairgowrie]], [[Perth and Kinross]], Scotland, 10 miles ENE of [[Pitlochry]]. The Dirnanean estate is situated adjacent to the 64 mile waymarked [[Cateran Trail]].
Dirnanean's steading house, lime kiln and shepherd's house are all [[Listed building (United Kingdom)#Scotland|Category B listed]] buildings.<ref name="Grade B Building Listing">{{cite web|title=British Listed Buildings|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/search?q=dirnanean|publisher=BritishListedBuildings.co.uk|accessdate=15 February 2014}}</ref>
The name Dirnanean is likely a derivation of Gaelic term Dur-nan-eun meaning "''the birds' water''"<ref name="Dirnanean in Gaelic">{{cite web|author1=Colonel James Alexander Robertson, F.S.A. Scot|title=Concise historical proofs respecting the Gael of Alban; or, Highlanders of Scotland, as descended of the Caledonian Picts, with the origin of the Irish Scots ... With explanatory notes, map, illustrations, and descriptions of the Country of the Gael|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mrtXAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA221&dq=%22of+dirnanean%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwji7JPLlMjRAhWJKGMKHVhuC3Y4KBDoAQgcMAE#v=onepage&q=%22of%20dirnanean%22&f=false|website=Google Books|accessdate=17 January 2017|page=221|date=1866}}</ref> or alternately, but similarly, Doire nan Eun meaning "bird grove".<ref name="Mount Blair Archive Meaning of Place Names">{{cite web|author1=Hamish Robertson|title=Placesnames of Strathardle, Glenshee and Glenisla|url=http://www.mountblairarchive.org/content/the_written_word/meaning-of-place-names-2|website=Mount Blair Archive|accessdate=29 May 2017|page=2|date=October 1996}}</ref>
==History of the Estate== A 1588 charter record states that Andrew Small was granted the lands of Dirnanean in Strathardle by John, the 5th Stewart Earl of Atholl.<ref name="Scottish Diaries">{{cite book|last=John|first=Kerr|title=Queen Victoria's Scottish Diaries|year=1992|publisher=Eric Dobby Publishing|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1-85882-018-9|pages=146‚Äì159}}</ref> By the time [[James Small (Scottish laird)|James Small]] (1835‚Äì1900) inherited the estate on the death of his father, Patrick, Dirnanean had been passed from father to son for nine generations.<ref name="Scottish Diaries" /> When James Small died without a direct heir, the ownership of Dirnanean transitioned to a series of his nephews until Francis Keir Balfour, the owner of neighboring [[Kindrogan House]], purchased the estate in 1926. A distant Small family cousin through his mother, Amelia Jane Keir, Francis Keir Balfour continued the Small family ownership of Dirnanean into the 1970s.
In 1790, [[Kirkmichael, Perth and Kinross|Kirkmichael]], Scotland musician Robert Petrie (1767‚Äì1830) published several Highland music pieces with "Mrs. Small of Dirnanean" in their title. The compositions were published in "Petrie's Collection of Strathspey Reels & County Dances".<ref name="Robert Petrie">{{cite web|last=Gatherer|first=Nigel|title=Robert Petrie's First Collection|url=http://www.nigelgatherer.com/tunes/abc/petr.html|accessdate=20 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="Traditional Tune Archive">{{cite web|title=Traditional Tune Archive|url=http://tunearch.org/wiki/Annotation:Mrs._Small_of_Dirnanean's_Jigg|accessdate=15 February 2014|quote=The Semantic Index of North American, British and Irish traditional instrumental music with annotation, formerly known as}}</ref>
Dirnanean is now privately owned by a non-relative.
===Smalls of Dirnanean=== [[File:Small Family Coat of Arms - Scotland.jpg|right|thumb|Small Coat of Arms]] [[File:Small Family Motto Button Found at Dirnanean, Scotland.jpg|right|thumb|Small Family Button]]
The Smalls are a [[sept]] of the Scottish [[Clan Murray]] of [[Murray of Atholl|Atholl]].
The Small family [[Coat of arms]] is described as "Per [[fess]]e, wavy, [[Heraldry#Tinctures|gu.]] and arg., a lion [[Attitude (heraldry)#Passant|passant]] sa., pierced through with a daggar, in bend, ppr. entering at shoulder, hilted, or", which translates to, divided in half horizontally (in the manner of a fess or band), wavy, [[gules]] (red) and [[argent]] (silver), a lion walking with a forepaw raised, [[sable (heraldry)|sable]] (black), pierced through with a [[dagger]], in bend, proper entering at shoulder, [[hilt]]ed, gold.<ref name="The British Herald">{{cite book|last=Robson|first=Thomas|title=The British herald; or, Cabinet of armorial bearings of the nobility & gentry of Great Britain & Ireland, from the earliest to the present time|year=1830|publisher=Turner & Marwood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=03EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT475&dq=Ratione+non+ira+small&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HWuZUpPdNILWoASl24HADw&ved=0CE0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Ratione%20non%20ira%20small&f=false|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref>
The Small family [[Scottish heraldry#Mottoes|motto]] is "''Ratione non ira''", which translates to "''By reason not rage''".<ref name="The General Armory of England">{{cite book|last=Burke|first=Bernard|title=The General Armory of England, Scotland, Ireland, and Wales, Comprising a Registry of Armorial Bearings from the Earliest to the Present Time, Volume 3|publisher=Heritage Books|page=1179|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X8UujEDqn9oC&pg=PA1179&dq=Ratione+non+ira+small&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HWuZUpPdNILWoASl24HADw&ved=0CEgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=30 November 2013|quote=Mottoes, Qu - Sa}}</ref> The Small family [[Scottish heraldry#Crests|crest]] is branch of palm, properly erect.<ref name="The British Herald" /> A gold button bearing an erect palm surrounded by the Small family motto was recently dug up in a garden plot on the Dirnanean estate.
A number of notable individuals are descendants or related by marriage to the Smalls of Dirnanean.
* Rev. [[Robert Blair (minister)|Robert Blair]], Scottish minister * [[Duncan Cameron (Scottish inventor)|Duncan Cameron]], owner of ''[[The Oban Times]]'' newspaper and [[inventor]] of The "''Waverley''" [[nib (pen)|nib]] [[pen]] * [[Mary Cameron (painter)|Mary Cameron]], Scottish [[painter]] * General [[Sir Archibald Campbell, 1st Baronet]], [[Order of the Bath|GCB]], administrator of the colony of [[New Brunswick]], [[Canada]] * General [[Sir John Campbell, 2nd Baronet]], Campbell Baronetcy of [[New Brunswick]], [[Canada]] * [[Conrad Corfield|Sir Conrad Laurence Corfield]], British official and a political secretary of [[Lord Mountbatten]] * [[Eric Norman Spencer Crankshaw|Sir Eric Norman Spencer Crankshaw]], {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KCMG|CMG|MBE}}, English [[cricket]]er, military officer and [[Civil service|civil servant]] * [[Alfred Crowfoot|Alfred Henchman Crowfoot]], Dean of Quebec, 1927 - 1947 * [[Brigadier]] [[John Cecil Currie]] {{postnominals|country=GBR|DSO**|MC}}, British Army Officer during WWII * [[William Purdie Dickson]], Professor of Divinity at the University of Glasgow * [[Daniel Dow]], traditional Scottish musician and composer * [[Charles Falconer, Baron Falconer of Thoroton|Charles Falconer]], Baron Falconer of Thoroton * Sir [[John Ireland Falconer]], former [[Lord Provost]] of [[Edinburgh]], 1944-1947 * [[Mrs. Alexander Fraser]], aka Caroline Rosetta Small Fraser, [[Victorian era]] [[novelist]] * [[Michael Hadow|Sir Reginald Michael Hadow]], British diplomat * [[Abdol Hossein Hamzavi]], an Iranian diplomat, author and representative to the United Nations * [[Charles Hylton Stewart|Arthur Charles Lestoc Hylton-Stewart]], organist of [[St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]] * [[Archibald Hope, Lord Rankeillor|Sir Archibald Hope]], Scottish judge stylized Lord Rankeillor * [[Sir John Hope, 2nd Baronet|Sir John Hope]], 2nd Baronet [[Hope baronets#Hope baronets, of Craighall (1628)|Hope of Craighall]], Scottish judge stylized Lord Craighall * [[Sir Thomas Hope, 1st Baronet|Sir Thomas Hope]], 1st Baronet Hope of Craighall, [[Advocate]] to [[King Charles I of England|Charles I]] * [[James Woffendale Inches|Dr. James W. Inches]], former [[Police Commissioner]] of [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] * [[James Inglis (physician)|Dr. James Inglis]], physician, author and geologist * [[Frederick Schomberg Ireland]], amateur cricketer and lawyer * [[George Ireland (businessman)|George Ireland]], one of the founders of [[Ireland Blyth Limited|Ireland Fraser & Co.]] * [[John Ireland (cricketer)|John Frederick Ireland]], amateur [[cricket]]er * [[Sheila Legge]], [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] [[performance artist]] * [[John Lodwick]], British novelist * [[Flora Macaulay]], editor of [[The Oban Times]] [[Newspaper]] * [[John MacDonald of Garth]], Canadian fur trader * [[Rolland Macdonald]], Canadian [[lawyer]] and [[judge]] * [[James Macgregor (MP)|James Macgregor]], (1808-1858), British politician and businessman * [[William McGillivray]], Canadian fur trader * [[Andrew Munro (mathematician)|Andrew Munro]], fellow, lecturer in mathematics and bursar at [[Queens' College, Cambridge]] * Sir William Nairne, [[Lord Dunsinane]], 5th Baronet of Nairne * [[Monica Poole]], English wood-engraver * Dr. [[Charles Ransford]], Fellow at the [[Royal College of Physicians]], [[Edinburgh]] and early advocate of [[homoeopathy]] * [[Patrick Francis Robertson]], British politician and businessman * [[Alexander Small (Scottish army surgeon)|Alexander Small]], Scottish army surgeon and correspondent of [[Benjamin Franklin]] * [[Charlotte Small]], early Canadian explorer * [[Henry Beaumont Small]], Canadian [[civil servant]] and [[author]] * [[James Small (Scottish factor)|James Small]], [[Factor (Scotland)|Factor]] of forfeited Straun Estates * [[James Small (Scottish laird)|James Small]], [[Laird]] of Dirnanean * Major-General [[John Small (British Army officer)|John Small]], (1726‚Äì1796), active in the [[American Revolutionary War]] * [[John Small (British Army medical officer)|Dr. John Small]], (1823-1879), British Deputy Surgeon General * [[John Small (librarian)|John Small]], (1828‚Äì1886), [[Librarian]] of [[Edinburgh University]] for 32 years * Lt. Col. [[John James Snodgrass]], (1796-1841), British military officer and author * [[Charles Spalding]], (1783-1783), [[Edinburgh]] [[confectioner]] and improver of the [[diving bell]] * [[Augustus Spencer|General the Hon. Sir Augustus Almeric Spencer, G.C.B.]], third son of Sir [[Francis Spencer, 1st Baron Churchill]] * The Reverend [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] [[Henry Spencer Stephenson]], [[Master's degree|M.A.]] (1871-1957), [[Chaplain]] to [[George VI|King George VI]] and [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] * [[Joan V. Stiebel]], [[MBE]], Jewish refugee worker * [[Francis Arthur Sutton]], and English adventurer * [[David Thompson (explorer)|David Thompson]], (1770-1857), early Canadian explorer * [[John Sen Inches Thomson]], (1845-1933), [[Scottish culture|Scottish]] [[whaling|whaler]] and [[seal hunting|sealer]], [[ship owner]], [[Captain (nautical)|captain]] and author * [[Brigadier-general (United Kingdom)|Brigadier General]] [[Sydney Frederick Williams]], [[Royal Engineers]]
===Queen Victoria's Visits=== [[File:"Queen Vic" plaque near Kindrogan - geograph.org.uk - 599299.jpg|right|thumb|Queen Victoria Plaque Between Dirnanean and Kindrogan]]
[[Queen Victoria]] passed through the lands of Dirnanean in 1865 and again in 1866, on her way from [[Balmoral Castle]] to [[Dunkeld]] via the [[Spittal of Glenshee]]. The visit in 1865 included a brief stop at Dirnanean House before a more extended visit at [[Kindrogan House]].<ref name="Scottish Diaries" /> A plaque set into the hillside between Dirnanean and Kindrogan marks the spot where the travelers had tea on the 1866 visit.
Today, Dirnanean House provides hikers on the Cateran Trail a hut for lunch or shelter very near the spot where Queen Victoria stopped for a [[picnic]].<ref name="The Cateran Trail">{{cite web|title=The Cateran Trail|url=http://www.caterantrail.org/trail/stage-2/the-upper-lunch-hut|work=The Upper Lunch Hut|accessdate=4 December 2012}}</ref>
===Historic description of the estate=== [[File: James Small in Dirnanean Summer House, July 1883.jpg|thumb|left|180px|James Small in the Dirnanean Summer House]] An 1880 description<ref name="Scottish Diaries" /> of the Dirnanean estate described it as follows:
:''They byres and stables are kept remarkably tidy being paragons of cleanliness in their way: while the dairy etc., are a perfect treat. The various kinds of stock grace their habitation. The accommodation of the farm servants is really comfortable. The policy grounds are very tastefully laid out, and the avenue is one of the nicest to be seen. A fine burn runs along the east side of the steading, the mansion and the avenue and joins the Ardle at the hamlet of Enochdhu. The burn flows through a deep den, which is prettily laid out with walks and rockeries and constructed with 'creature stones'. Here, also, is a nice heather or summer house perched on a precipice, overhanging a still pool and from which a charming view is obtained of two small cascades. The approach is also very lovely. Ardle's grave is situated here. ''
===The Perthshire Eagle=== [[File:Dirnanean Eagle Postcard.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Eagle's Cage Postcard]]
For 37 years, until its death in 1908, an eagle was kept in captivity in a metal and thatched cage next to the Dirnanean Burn.<ref name="Perthshire Eagle" /> Taken when young from its nest near the [[Kirkton of Glenisla]],<ref name="Perthshire Eagle">{{cite news|title=Perthshire Captive Eagle|newspaper=The Scotsman Newspaper, Edinburgh, Scotland|date=September 21, 1908|page=6}}</ref> the eagle was fed mainly on game by the estate staff.
The Perthshire Eagle was a popular [[Perthshire]] attraction during its residence at Dirnanean. Several postcards depicting the eagle in its cage next the Dirnanean Burn were issued to draw Victorian travellers to the Dirnanean area.
Partial remnants of the eagle's cage can still be seen along the Dirnanean Burn walk.
==Features==
===Dirnanean Garden=== The estate's traditional highland garden area includes 1.5 hectares of garden plantings with 7 hectares of policies located 1,000 feet above sea level.
Features within the garden include a refurbished summer house on the front lawn, a walled garden, a burn walk with cascades, a traditional estate kitchen garden with an orchard, a [[greenhouse]] and poterage, and a small museum of garden tools discovered during the refurbishment of the garden and the grounds. The summer house sits on a turntable that allows the entire structure to be pivoted to face the sunlight as it moves across the lawn.
[[Peafowl|Peacocks]] and [[guineafowl]]s can often be seen roaming the grounds, and a [[Sequoiadendron giganteum|Wellingtonia]] (Sequoiadendron giganteum) specimen tree bordering the front lawn is estimated to have been planted around 1870. <ref name="Big Tree Country">{{cite web|title=Big Tree Country|url=http://www.perthshirebigtreecountry.co.uk/places/pitlochry-road-isles/dirnanean-garden|accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref>
The garden is accessible by the public for a small fee.
<gallery> File:Dirnanean Garden Lawn.jpg|Front Lawn File:Garden Museum.jpg|Garden Museum File:Wild Foxgloves - geograph.org.uk - 79907.jpg|Wild Foxgloves File:Fowl_House_and_Barns_at_Dirnanean_House,_Scotland.jpg|Fowl House and Barns File:Dirnanean_Estate_Scotland_Wellingtonia.jpg| Wellingtonia Specimen Tree Behind Refurbished Summer House </gallery>
===Dirnanean Burn=== One of the finest features of the estate is the Allt Doire-nan-Eun ([[Scottish Gaelic]]: ''Stream of the Thicket of the Fowl''), a stream flowing from high in the Dirnanean hills southwards through a deep wooded gorge on its way to the [[River Ardle]]. The burn includes several cascades, a small island and a walking trail that runs parallel to it as it winds through the estate.
<gallery> File:Dirnanean Estate Scotland Stream.jpg|Estate Stream File:Dirnanean Burn Waterfall.jpg|Burn Cascades File:Dirnanean Creature Stone and Folly.jpg|Folly & Creature Stone on Burn Walk File:Dirnanean Estate Scotland Field Rock.jpg|Field Boulder </gallery>
[[File:The Giant's Grave Barrow - geograph.org.uk - 1003378.jpg|Ardle's Grave|right|220px|thumb]]
===Ardle's Grave=== Near the former carriage entrance of Dirnanean House, close to the hamlet of Enochdhu lies the grave of a [[Pictish]] warrior named Ard-fhuil who gave his name to the surrounding area of Strathardle. Ard-fhuil was reputedly a giant and the length of the grave appears to confirm this but cynics believe one of his hencemen is buried at his feet! .<ref name="Ardle's Grave">{{cite web|title=Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historic Monuments of Scotland|url=http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/27581/details/ardle+s+grave/|work=Ardle's Grave|accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref> Local lore has it that during Victorian times, the [[laird]] of Dirnanean buried his horse at the spot as a garden amusement.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.caterantrail.org/trail/stage-2/the-upper-lunch-hut Dirnanean Lunch Hut] *[http://www.mountblairarchive.org/content/galleries/places-galleries/enochdhu/dirnanean-estate Photos of Dirnanean]
