revision.comment: /* Ayahuasca */Typo fixing, replaced: an [[Quechua language]] ‚Üí a [[Quechua language]]
revision.text:
[[File:Chimarraocuia.JPG|thumb|Mate infusion served in ''chimarr√£o cuia'' style.]] [[File:Japanese Immigrants in tea Plantation 01.jpg|thumb|A Brazilian tea plantation around 1930. Tea leaves are harvested in this photo by Japanese immigrants.]] '''Brazilian tea culture''' has its origins in the [[infusion|infused beverages]], or ''ch√°s'' ({{IPA-pt|Àà Éas}}), made by the indigenous cultures of the Amazon region and the R√≠o de la Plata basin. It has evolved since the Portuguese colonial period to include imported varieties and tea-drinking customs. There is a popular belief in Brazil that Brazilians, especially the urban ones, have a greater taste for using [[sugar]] in teas than in other cultures, being unused to unsweetened drinks.
==Yerba-mate== A popular [[caffeine|caffeinated]] infusion is [[Mate (beverage)|mate]], made from the leaves of the native [[yerba mate]] plant. In Brazil, the plant is called ''erva-mate'' or simply ''mate'', and the hot beverage drunk from a [[calabash]] [[gourd]] is called ''chimarr√£o'', typically associated with the southernmost state, [[Rio Grande do Sul]]. Mate is a popular beverage in other South American countries as well, specially around the people that lives in the southern region, which comprises the named [[Gaucho]] culture, or the culture from the Pampas. [[Argentina]], [[Paraguay]], and [[Uruguay]]. Specially in the Paraguayan and in a few parts of the northern Argentinian border, the mate is also drunk infused in cold water along the daytime, and receives the name of Terere. As in other South American countries, mate is traditionally drunk from a hollow gourd using a silver straw, a tradition that continues from indigenous cultures who introduced mate to colonists, though in other parts of the country, processed mate is drunk iced, as a non-carbonated [[soft drink]].
==Common modern varieties== [[Camellia sinensis|True teas]] such as [[black tea]] (''ch√°-preto'') are popular in Brazil, either hot or iced. Brazilians also have their own local modern variations of flavored and herbal teas. [[Lemongrass]] teas are popular.<ref>{{cite web|title=Recipe: :Lemongrass tea|url=http://www.chai-tea-recipes.com/recipes/lemongrass-chai-tea-recipe/|publisher=Chai Tea Recipes|accessdate=Jan 1, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203165536/http://www.chai-tea-recipes.com/recipes/lemongrass-chai-tea-recipe/#|archive-date=2012-02-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Lemongrass is a plant imported from [[Southeast Asia]], which grows well in Brazil's climate. Lemongrass is called ''capim-santo'', ''capim-lim√£o'' or ''capim cidreira''. It is generally consumed in [[herbal tea]]s and health drinks, which is its primary culinary use in Brazil. Like many infusions in Brazil, lemongrass beverages are considered more medicinal than culinary. One iced drink made of lemongrass and pineapple peelings is called ''ch√° de abacaxi com capim-santo''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Recipe: Pineapple and lemongrass tea|url=http://flavorsofbrazil.blogspot.com/2010/05/recipe-pineapple-and-lemongrass-tea-cha.html|publisher=Flavors of Brazil|accessdate=October 23, 2011}}</ref>
Alongside lemongrass and mate, infusions from plants cultivated domestically or in local little properties usually served as everyday drinks are ''[[Melissa officinalis]]'', the lemon balm, there known as ''erva-cidreira'' or ''citronela'', ''[[Mentha]]'', the mint, there known as ''hortel√£'' ({{IPA-pt|oÃû ÅteÃûÀàl…êÃÉ|IPA}}) (though juices are much more popular ‚Äì tea is usually made from processed dried mint in the market), ''[[Kyllinga]] odorata'', in the genus of the plants known as spikesedges, there known as ''[[:pt:capim-cidreira|capim-cidreira]]'', ''[[Foeniculum vulgare]]'', the fennel, there known as ''erva-doce'' or ''funcho'', ''[[Pimpinella anisum]]'', the anise, there known as ''erva-doce'' or rarely ''anis'', ''[[Illicium verum]]'', the Chinese star anise, there known as ''anis-estrelado'', ''[[Aloysia citrodora]]'', the South American lemon verbena, there known as ''l√∫cia-lima'', among some other American, European and Asian plants.
{{Further|Traditional Brazilian medicine}}
Examples of plants commonly cultivated domestically in Brazil for medicinal uses are ''[[Peumus boldus]]'', the boldo, there known as ''boldo-do-chile'', ''[[Plectranthus barbatus]]'', the Indian coleus, there known as ''boldo-de-jardim'' or ''boldo-da-terra'', ''[[Plantago major]]'', the greater plantain, there known as ''tanchagem'', ''[[Vernonia]] condensata'', there known as ''[[:pt:Boldo-baiano|boldo-baiano]]'', ''Vernonia polysphaera'', there known as ''[[:pt:Assa-peixe|assa-peixe]]'', ''Chenopodium ambrosioides'', there known as ''[[:pt:Erva-de-santa-maria|erva-de-santa-maria]]'', ''[[Dysphania ambrosioides]]'', the epazote, also known in Brazil as ''erva-de-santa-maria'', ''Baccharis trimera'', there known as ''[[:pt:Carqueja|carqueja]]'', ''Maytenus ilicifolia'', there known as ''[[:pt:Espinheira-santa|espinheira-santa]]'', ''[[Rhamnus purshiana]]'', the cascara buckthorn, there known as ''c√°scara sagrada'', ''[[Echinodorus]] grandiflorus'', there known as ''[[:pt:chap√©u-de-couro|chap√©u-de-couro]]'', ''[[Uncaria tomentosa]]'', the cat's claw, there known as ''unha-de-gato'', ''[[Mimosa tenuiflora]]'', the tepezcohuite, there known as ''jurema-preta'', among others.
==Indigenous teas== There are many indigenous [[herb]]s consumed as herbal teas in Brazil, which often have traditional medicinal uses. Some varieties are consumed as part of native religious rituals.
===Mint tea=== Mint tea, an infusion made from the brewed leaves of the plant ''[[Hyptis crenata]]'', has been used by traditional healers to cure headaches, fevers and flu. Graciela Rocha, in research conducted for [[Newcastle University]], found the drink to be as effective as a synthetic aspirin-style drug, Indometacin: {{blockquote|Rocha, who is Brazilian and remembers being given the tea as a cure for every childhood illness, said: "The taste isn't what most people here in the UK would recognise as a mint. In fact it tastes more like sage which is another member of the mint family.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bowcott|first=Owen|title=Brazilian mint tea 'as effective as pain-relief drugs'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2009/nov/25/brazilian-mint-tea-pain-relief-drugs|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 25, 2009}}</ref>}}
===Ayahuasca=== [[Ayahuasca]], which means "vine of souls" in a [[Quechua language]], has a history going back to ancient times. It is a traditional drink used in spiritual and healing rituals. The drink is used in the religions of [[Santo Daime]] and "[[Uni√£o do Vegetal]]". It has purgative, nauseating and [[hallucinogenic]] properties.
Due to its hallucinogenic effects, its legal status in Brazil has met with controversy from authorities outside Brazil. The active ingredient that produces hallucinations, [[Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]], is considered a [[Class A drug]] (the same label given to [[heroin]] and [[cocaine]]) by the U.S. and the U.K. However, in 2010 Brazil's national anti-drug body approved the consumption of the drink for religious rituals after decades of studies and talks with religious institutions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil legalizes hallucinogenic tea|url=http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_sa/2010-03-10/489370314058.html|publisher=NTDTV|accessdate=October 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120711134726/http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_sa/2010-03-10/489370314058.html|archivedate=July 11, 2012|df=}}</ref>
==History== During the colonial era, imported tea varieties were first cultivated in Brazil in 1812. Throughout the 19th century, the tea industry, much like the coffee industry, was heavily dependent on slave labor to work on the plantations. When slavery was abolished in 1888, the tea trade collapsed. In the 1920s, the tea industry was revived by Japanese immigrants, who introduced tea seeds from [[Sri Lanka]] and India. Prior to this time, only Chinese tea varieties had been grown in Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tea from Brazil|url=http://www.teagenius.com/other-tea-growing-areas/tea-from-brazil.html|publisher=Tea Genius|accessdate=October 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506060126/http://www.teagenius.com/other-tea-growing-areas/tea-from-brazil.html|archivedate=May 6, 2009|df=}}</ref>
Brazil's largest tea-producing region is near [[Registro]], a coastal city near [[S√£o Paulo]]. Registro is in the [[Brazilian Highlands]] and forms a terrain of low rolling hills that are ideal for mechanized tea production. The growing season in Brazil is from September to April; the climate is hot and humid. The relatively low altitude of most of Brazil's tea plantations, however, produces a tea which is less flavorful than high altitude teas. For this reason, Brazilian teas are most often produced for blending. The tea is used for both iced tea and hot tea blends with about 70% of the total tea production being sold to the United States.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tea from Brazil|url=http://www.teagenius.com/other-tea-growing-areas/tea-from-brazil.html|publisher=Tea Genius|accessdate=October 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506060126/http://www.teagenius.com/other-tea-growing-areas/tea-from-brazil.html|archivedate=May 6, 2009|df=}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Brazil}} * [[Tea]] * [[Mate (beverage)]] * [[Traditional medicine]] * [[Health effects of tea]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Teas}}
[[Category:Tea culture by country]] [[Category:Tea in South America]] [[Category:Traditional medicine]] [[Category:Brazilian drinks]]

page.title: If I Could Fall in Love

revision.comment: Applying general fixes for links, HTML, and/or references
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox song | name = If I Could Fall in Love | cover = lenny_kravitz-if_i_could_fall_in_love_s_1.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Lenny Kravitz]] | album = [[Lenny (album)|Lenny]] | released = July 30, 2002 | format = {{hlist|[[CD single|CD]]|[[maxi single|maxi CD]]}} | recorded = | studio = | venue = [[DIC]]{{dn|date=January 2019}} | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | length = 4:12 | label = [[Virgin Records|Virgin America]] | writer = {{hlist|Lenny Kravitz|[[Craig Ross]]}} | producer = {{hlist|Lenny Kravitz|Craig Ross}} | prev_title = [[Believe in Me (Lenny Kravitz song)|Believe in Me]] | prev_year = 2002 | next_title = Yesterday Is Gone | next_year = 2002 }} "'''If I Could Fall in Love'''" is the fourth single by American rock musician [[Lenny Kravitz]]'s 2001 sixth self-titled studio album ''[[Lenny (album)|Lenny]]'', released on December 24, 2002 by [[Virgin Records|Virgin Records America]].{{cite web|title=If I Could Fall in Love [Holland CD] ‚Äì Lenny Kravitz ‚Äì Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/if-i-could-fall-in-love-holland-cd-r622554|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=October 23, 2011}} The single was part of the soundtrack of the film ''[[Blue Crush]]'' (2002), as the main theme.{{cite news|title=Lenny Kravitz ‚Äì IMDB ‚Äì Soundtrack|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005107/|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=[[IMDB]]}} ==Track listing== #"If I Could Fall in Love" [Vocal Up] ‚Äì (4:12) #"If I Could Fall in Love" [Album Version] ‚Äì (4:24) #"[[Stillness of Heart]]" [Amsterdam Acoustic Version] ‚Äì (8:16) #"If I Could Fall in Love" ‚Äì (10:50) ==Music video== The music video features Lenny performing the song in various locations including a beach and a swimming pool. Amplifiers and speakers are set up to give the viewers the impression that they are attending a special concert as well as the actors of the film ''Blue Crush'', including [[Kate Bosworth]] and [[Michelle Rodriguez]] on the beach.{{cite news|title="If I Could Fall in Love" ‚Äì Lenny Kravitz|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1a6eofhWu0A|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=YouTube}} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" |- !align="left"|Chart (2002) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |New Zealand ([[RIANZ]]){{cite news|title=Lenny Kravitz ‚Äì If I Could Fall in Love ‚Äì austriancharts.at|url=http://austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Lenny+Kravitz&titel=If+I+Could+Fall+In+Love&cat=s|accessdate=October 23, 2011|newspaper=Hung Medien}} | style="text-align:center;"|98 |- |align="left"|Switzerland ([[Swiss Music Charts|Schweizer Hitparade]]) | style="text-align:center;"|85 |- |[[Adult Top 40|US Adult Top 40]]{{cite web|title=Lenny Kravitz ‚Äì Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lenny-kravitz-p4708/charts-awards/billboard-singles|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=October 23, 2011}} | style="text-align:center;"|40 |} ==External links== *[http://lennykravitz.com/ Lenny Kravitz official site] * {{MetroLyrics song|lenny-kravitz|if-i-could-fall-in-love}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Lenny Kravitz singles}} [[Category:2002 singles]] [[Category:Lenny Kravitz songs]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Lenny Kravitz]] [[Category:Songs written by Lenny Kravitz]]

revision.text: :''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''delete'''. [[User:Ron Ritzman|Ron Ritzman]] ([[User talk:Ron Ritzman|talk]]) 00:21, 31 October 2011 (UTC) ===[[Korean players' victories on LPGA Tour]]=== :{{la|Korean players' victories on LPGA Tour}} ‚Äì ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Korean players' victories on LPGA Tour|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2011 October 23#{{anchorencode:Korean players' victories on LPGA Tour}}|View log]]) :({{Find sources|Korean players' victories on LPGA Tour}}) This article is WP:OVERCAT. It is not realistic to have a list for every country that has had winners on the LPGA and a list of each winner, tournament and date of win. There is no reason to do this for Korea and not for USA, England, Sweden, etc. Instead I propose that a new article be created: Winners of LPGA Tour Event by Nation. This would include a list of countries that have had winners on the LPGA, the number of winners, and the winning year span. --[[User:Crunch|Crunch]] ([[User talk:Crunch|talk]]) 15:00, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete.''' Per my nom. Example of [[WP:OVERCAT]]. --[[User:Crunch|Crunch]] ([[User talk:Crunch|talk]]) 15:03, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete''' The success of Korean woman golfers is certainly notable, and probably deserves an article. (Is there one on African-American sports success?) However this list is really just raw data. It belongs on the sports page, not an encyclopedia. [[User:BigJim707|BigJim707]] ([[User talk:BigJim707|talk]]) 15:52, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete''' [[WP:OVERCAT]] is for categories only, it doesn't qualify for lists, but this is a perfect example of [[WP:NOT#STATS]] [[User:Secret|Secret]] [[User talk:Secret|account]] 19:55, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Golf|list of Golf-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:51, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Lists|list of Lists-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:52, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.
#REDIRECT [[Georges Stern]]

:''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''delete'''. [[User:Spartaz|Spartaz]] ''[[User talk:Spartaz|Humbug!]]'' 04:46, 8 November 2011 (UTC) ===[[Ragged Crow]]=== :{{la|Ragged Crow}} ‚Äì ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Ragged Crow|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2011 October 31#{{anchorencode:Ragged Crow}}|View log]]) :({{Find sources|Ragged Crow}}) Independent film company of questionable notability. Possibly some notability for some of their projects or individuals, but a Google search on "Ragged Crow" shows a wealth of primary sources, social media and sales links, but no significant coverage from independent reliable sources found in the first 10 pages of results. Article appears to have been created/edited by a pair of SPAs doing nothing but creating promotional articles for this company, its principals, and its projects. [[User:MikeWazowski|MikeWazowski]] ([[User talk:MikeWazowski|talk]]) 14:51, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Ragged Crow is listed in the British Council Films Catalogue as the production company in the entry for Stealing Elvis, it is also listed on IMDb... Ragged Crow is notable for having made many films that have screened at Filmstock, Norwich Independent Film Festival, Portobello Film Festival, Rushes Soho Shorts Film Festival, London Independent Film Festival, Crystal Palace Film Festival, London Short Film Festival over a period since 2008... It emphasises quality low budget film-making and has a reputation in the underground film-making community... I do think it a shame if notabiltiy is mostly indemnified by a google search, which may vary from user to user, because of their preferences... I believe strongly that people who make films will want to know what this company does... ‚Äî Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Seditonary|Seditonary]] ([[User talk:Seditonary|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Seditonary|contribs]]) 15:03, 23 October 2011 (UTC) ‚Äî [[User:Seditonary|Seditonary]] ([[User talk:Seditonary|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Seditonary|contribs]]) has made [[Wikipedia:Single-purpose account|few or no other edits]] outside this topic. :As an addendum, surely IMDb, British Council & Plectrum TCP are bona fide secondary sources?...--[[User:Seditonary|Seditonary]] ([[User talk:Seditonary|talk]]) 15:31, 23 October 2011 (UTC)Seditionary ::Please review [[WP:RS]]. IMDB is suitable as a jumping off point for guiding one in searches, but is not considered reliable enough as a citation. [[British Council]] Film is reliable enough to [[WP:V|verify]] the company's existance (though I do not think that is in doubt), but simply being in their catalog does not confer a notability. Please read [[WP:CORP]] to better understand Wikipedia requirements for showing a company as notable. '''[[User:MichaelQSchmidt|Schmidt,]]''' ''[[User talk:MichaelQSchmidt|MICHAEL Q.]]'' 00:44, 24 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Film|list of Film-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:48, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Business|list of Business-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:48, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. There's no reliable sources to show notability. IMDb does not automatically give you notability, nor does being listed in the BCF listings. Fails [[WP:GNG]]. [[User:Tokyogirl79|Tokyogirl79]] ([[User talk:Tokyogirl79|talk]]) 11:25, 24 October 2011 (UTC)tokyogirl79 Isn't Wikipedia supposed to be an encyclopedic platform that "''anyone'' can edit use modify and distriblute"? (''- Wikipedia: Five Pillars''). A platform that does not "apply hard and fast rules" (''- Wikipedia: Policies and Guidelines''). Ragged Crow may not be Miramax or A Band Apart, but they they have had a four year history of making short films, that have screened at reputable festivals, and a feature, which might be considered noteworthy precisely ''because'' it was produced for ¬£5 grand for 7 days of filming - cross ref with other films that are notable for their achievement despite low budgets such as The Blair Witch Project. I am a new contributor and understand that I might be met with with certain suspicion, but is this a case of "bite the newbie"? Many articles in Wikipedia must have had lowly beginnings. I am not saying that this article is full and complete, but I do reiterate that it is a decent enough starting off point for a subject that can be expanded upon... From an acorn does an oak grow... And I do believe that aspiring film-makers are interested in seeing small independent film production companies included on Wikipedia... If in the future Ragged Crow proves to do nothing more than they have already, then of course this should be reviewed. But Wikipedia (''Five Pillars'') encourages contributors to "be bold" (but not reckless) and as such I think this article should be given a chance, and when more citations and references become available, I will endeavour to add them... I might even find that other contributors by then are interested enough to do likewise... --[[User:Seditonary|Seditonary]] ([[User talk:Seditonary|talk]]) 08:59, 26 October 2011 (UTC)‚Äî [[User:Seditonary|Seditonary]] ([[User talk:Seditonary|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Seditonary|contribs]]) has made [[Wikipedia:Single-purpose account|few or no other edits]] outside this topic. :[[WP:SECONDARY]] says, "Wikipedia articles should be based on reliable, published secondary sources." That is what we need here, especially to satisfy the notability guideline outlined at [[WP:ORG]] and to be able to cover this topic in an encyclopedic manner. The same goes for other topics closely related to Ragged Crow. I would suggest reading [[Wikipedia:Conflict of interest]] if you are personally involved with any of these topics. [[User:Erik|Erik]] ([[User talk:Erik|talk]] | [[Special:Contributions/Erik|contribs]]) 13:41, 26 October 2011 (UTC)
:'''[[WP:RELIST|Relisted]] to generate a more thorough discussion so a clearer consensus may be reached.'''
:Please add new comments below this notice. Thanks, [[User:Ron Ritzman|Ron Ritzman]] ([[User talk:Ron Ritzman|talk]]) 00:23, 31 October 2011 (UTC)
*'''Delete'''. Ragged Crow as a production company has no notability separate from that of its principals, [[Sam Edwards (poet, writer & independent film producer)|Sam Edwards]] and [[Ed Edwards]], and all of its films are already mentioned in both Sam and Ed's articles. It appears that none of Ragged Crow's films have gone on general release anywhere yet, just been shown at film festivals. (And screenings at the [[Portobello Film Festival]] won't count much toward notability; the festival screens every film that is submitted to it.) Contrary to what Seditonary wrote above, a film does not become notable just for being low budget -- there are lots of low-budget films that don't receive distribution and aren't covered in Wikipedia. What is particularly notable is when a low-budget film receives significant public attention, like what happened to ''[[The Blair Witch Project]]'' or ''[[Paranormal Activity]]''. A low-budget film that plays at a couple of film festivals and doesn't go on general release can't be compared to that. I suspect, however, that some of the negative reaction to this article may have come from the formatting problems. If [[User:Seditonary]], or another editor, will fix the formatting problems with [[Sam Edwards (poet, writer & independent film producer)]], [[Ed Edwards]], and/or [[Stealing Elvis]], then I'll refrain from recommending "delete" on those articles or nominating them for deletion myself. --[[User:Metropolitan90|Metropolitan90]] [[User talk:Metropolitan90|(talk)]] 01:40, 31 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. Ragged Crow hasn't received much coverage anywhere but the IMDb (which [[WP:IMDB|isn't a reliable source]]). Just take a look at [http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Ragged+Crow%22&tbm=nws&tbs=ar:1 the Google News archive search] (also linked at the top of the page) to see what I mean. None of the six results have anything to do with the company. Seditonary, if more outside references become available, then the inclusion of the article could be justifiable, but for now, it fails the [[WP:GNG|GNG]]. [[User:Crw21|Chris]] ([[User talk:Crw21|talk]]) 00:07, 6 November 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete''' On the basis of MQS's analysis. When in doubt about articles on this subject I rely upon MQS, who both knows the field and is sympathetic to my own view of being as inclusive as makes sense, We both know there's a limit, and the limit must be defended to prevent us degenerating into a mere directory. '''[[User:DGG| DGG]]''' ([[User talk:DGG| talk ]]) 14:56, 7 November 2011 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

:''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''delete'''. [[User:Spartaz|Spartaz]] ''[[User talk:Spartaz|Humbug!]]'' 04:46, 8 November 2011 (UTC) ===[[VELOCITY Broadcasting]]=== :{{la|VELOCITY Broadcasting}} ‚Äì ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/VELOCITY Broadcasting|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2011 October 31#{{anchorencode:VELOCITY Broadcasting}}|View log]]) :({{Find sources|VELOCITY Broadcasting}}) Ad-like article, written by [[WP:SPA]] named like Elias/Savion Advertising, Inc., on a company only known from its own press releases. [[User:Dicklyon|Dicklyon]] ([[User talk:Dicklyon|talk]]) 14:55, 23 October 2011 (UTC) * '''Support''' as nom. See the article talk page, where we've been talking about what to name it, which would have been easy if there had been any secondary sources. There's one press release for their new name, and nothing else about them recently, and nothing but their own releases before, too, so they don't pass [[WP:GNG]]. The creating [[WP:SPA]] editor is {{userlinks|EliasSavion}}, who is also in a [[WP:COI]] situation, per the statement in the article that ""Velocity World Media was founded as Velocity Broadcasting in December 2005 by Philip Elias, co-founder and president of Elias/Savion Advertising, Inc." According to this [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/eliassavion-advertising-receives-a-host-of-accolades-for-marketing-design-web-site-development-78226807.html Elias/Savion press release], they created the "VELOCITY Broadcasting Brochure: A high-impact corporate identity brochure with a unique oblong shape and a sophisticated design, this brochure features high-quality, glossy pages that provide an overview of VELOCITY Broadcasting and its capabilities." [[User:Dicklyon|Dicklyon]] ([[User talk:Dicklyon|talk]]) 14:59, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Comment''': It would be good to keep the talk page (and its history), as there are other interesting issues raised, and otherwise we risk reinventing the wheel when these come up again. [[User:Andrewa|Andrewa]] ([[User talk:Andrewa|talk]]) 19:55, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Is there a way to do that? And why? I don't see what's interesting about that naming discussion. [[User:Dicklyon|Dicklyon]] ([[User talk:Dicklyon|talk]]) 22:37, 23 October 2011 (UTC) ::Yes, there are several options, for example I'm happy to [[WP:userfy|userfy]] the talk page and its history. The discussion is presumably important to those who took the trouble to participate, of whom I am one (which is one reason it might be appropriate to move it to my own user talk space). If you're disinterested in the points made, that's fine too. [[User:Andrewa|Andrewa]] ([[User talk:Andrewa|talk]]) 23:14, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Television|list of Television-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:50, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Advertising|list of Advertising-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:50, 23 October 2011 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Business|list of Business-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|‚Ä¢ Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 22:50, 23 October 2011 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. Appears to be advertising added by a COI organization. Not seeing sufficient third-party sourcing to demonstrate notability. --[[User:DAJF|DAJF]] ([[User talk:DAJF|talk]]) 23:44, 27 October 2011 (UTC)
:'''[[WP:RELIST|Relisted]] to generate a more thorough discussion so a clearer consensus may be reached.'''
:Please add new comments below this notice. Thanks, [[User:Ron Ritzman|Ron Ritzman]] ([[User talk:Ron Ritzman|talk]]) 00:22, 31 October 2011 (UTC)
*'''Delete'''. Advertisement for a provider of in-house closed circuit entertainment for a couple of chain restaurants, apparently. It's hard to make that sound grandiose and important, but they get an F for Effort: ''From the WQED Multimedia studios in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its corporate offices in New York City and Pittsburgh, Velocity World Media produces interactive private TV programming in HD-high definition formats and utilizes a fully encrypted signal to deliver the programming live via EchoStar Satellite to invitation-only audiences. Those audiences gather at the Velocity HD Digital Suites, which are located in private dining rooms in Morton‚Äôs The Steakhouse and Maggiano‚Äôs Little Italy restaurants in 200 markets throughout the world.'' Ridiculous. - [[User:Ihcoyc|Smerdis of Tl√∂n]] - [[User talk:Ihcoyc|killing the human spirit since 2003!]] 14:33, 31 October 2011 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

page.title: List of petroleum and gas museums

revision.comment: Added an external link to the museum's webpage.
revision.text:
[[File:Norsk Oljemuseum.jpg|thumb|280px|The Norwegian Petroleum Museum is a civic landmark in Stavanger, Norway. This museum focuses mainly on petroleum exploration and production in the [[North Sea]].]]This is a '''list of petroleum, gas, and related museums''' around the world.
==Asia== * [[Oman Oil and Gas Exhibition Centre]], Al-Qurum * [[Petroleum Museum (Malaysia)|Petroleum Museum]], Malaysia * [[Taiwan Oil Field Exhibition Hall]], Taiwan * [[KOC Ahmed Al Jaber Oil and Gas Exhibition]], Kuwait
==Europe== [[File:Museo Fisogni exposition.jpg|thumb|A photo of Museo Fisogni, in Italy. It's the largest collection in the world, certified by Guinness World Record]] * [[Erd√∂l-Erdgas-Museum Twist]], Twist, Germany * [[German Oil Museum]], Lower Saxony, Germany * [[Muzeul Na»õional al Petrolului]], Ploiesti, Romania * [[:fr:Mus√©e du p√©trole de Merkwiller-Pechelbronn|Mus√©e du p√©trole de Merkwiller-Pechelbronn]] (in French) * [[Norwegian Petroleum Museum]], Stavanger, Norway * [http://www.oljeon.se/ Engelsbergs Oljefabrik], √Ñngelsberg, Sweden * [[Technopolis (Gazi)]], Athens, Greece * GASmuseet, The Danish GAS Museum, Hobro, Denmark * [http://www.bobrka.pl/en Ignacy ≈Åukasiewicz Oil and Gas Industry Museum], Bobrka, Poland * [[Warsaw Gasworks Museum]], Warsaw, Poland * [http://www.museodelpetrolio.it Project Parco Museo del Petrolio Vallezza] (Fornovo di Taro), Parma, Italy * [http://www.museo-fisogni.org/ Museo Fisogni], Tradate, Italy (largest gas pumps and petroliana collection, certified by [[Guinness World Records]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Museo Fisogni, la pi√π grande collezione di pompe di benzina del mondo apre nelle Giornate FAI|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2017/03/22/motori/museo-fisogni-la-pi-grande-collezione-di-pompe-di-benzina-del-mondo-apre-nelle-giornate-fai-21HlV0HciQchNgTRQH8NbL/pagina.html}}</ref>) * [https://www.facebook.com/MuzeumNaftovehoDobyvaniAGeologie Museum of Oil Mining and geology], Hodon√≠n, Czech republic * Magyar Olajipari M√∫zeum, Zalaegerszeg, Hungary
===United Kingdom=== * [http://www.dukeswoodoilmuseum.co.uk/ Dukes Wood Oil Museum], Nottinghamshire * [http://www.flamegasworks.co.uk/ Flame: the Gasworks Museum of Ireland] (formerly Carrickfergus Gas Works Museum), Belfast * [[London Gas Museum]] (closed) * [http://www.scottishshale.co.uk/ Museum of the Scottish Shale Oil Industry], Livingston * [[Gas Museum (Leicester)|National Gas Museum]], Leicester, UK

(Capacity: 21,000){{cite web|title=How Johnson Hagood Stadium Came To Be |url=http://www.citadelsports.com/information/insideAthletics/facilities/hagoodArticle |publisher=citadelsports.com |accessdate=September 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818173314/http://www.citadelsports.com/information/insideAthletics/facilities/hagoodArticle |archivedate=August 18, 2012 |df= }} | Champion = Tangerine Bowl champion | BowlTourney = [[1960 Tangerine Bowl (December)|Tangerine Bowl]] | BowlTourneyResult = W 27‚Äì0 vs {{cfb link|year=1960|team=Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles|title=Tennessee Tech}} }} {{1960 Southern Conference football standings}} The '''1960 The Citadel Bulldogs football team''' represented [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]] in the [[1960 NCAA football season]]. The Bulldogs were led by fourth year head coach [[Eddie Teague]] and played their home games at [[Johnson Hagood Stadium]]. They played as members of the [[Southern Conference]], as they have since 1936. In 1960, The Citadel won in its first and only bowl appearance in the [[1960 Tangerine Bowl (December)|Tangerine Bowl]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/conferences/southern/1960.html|title=1960 Southern Conference Year Summary|publisher=College Football at Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=2012-06-28}} revision.comment: /* Descendants */Typo fixing, replaced: all of who ‚Üí all of whom using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Marcus Junius M. f. M. n. Silanus Torquatus''' was [[Roman consul|consul]] in AD 19 with [[Lucius Norbanus Balbus]]. ==Biography== Silanus was a descendant of the noble Roman house of the [[Junia (gens)|Junii Silani]]. His grandfather was [[Marcus Junius Silanus (consul 25 BC)|Marcus Junius Silanus]], consul with the emperor [[Augustus]] in 25 BC. Torquatus married [[Aemilia Lepida (fiancee of Claudius)|Aemilia Lepida]], daughter of [[Julia the Younger]], and great-granddaughter of Augustus.''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]'', 2nd Ed. (1970).''[[Realencyclop√§die der Classischen Altertumswissenschaft]]''. Consul for the whole year of AD 19, he and his colleague Norbanus brought forward the ''[[lex Junia Norbana]]'', which prevented [[Slavery in ancient Rome|slaves]] manumitted by [[Praetor]]s from receiving the [[Roman citizenship|franchise]], and precluding their descendants from inheritance. [[Freedmen]] under this law came to be known as ''Latini Juniani''.''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]'', 2nd Ed. (1970). From AD 36 to about 39, Silanus was proconsul of [[Africa (Roman province)|Africa]].''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]'', 2nd Ed. (1970). ==Descendants== Silanus and Aemilia had five children, all of whom suffered as a result of their connection to the imperial family.[[Ronald Syme]], ''The Augustan Aristocracy'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1986), pp. 188, 192 * [[Marcus Junius Silanus Torquatus (consul AD 46)|Marcus Junius Silanus Torquatus]] (AD 14-54), consul in 46, put to death in order to ensure the succession of [[Nero]], and to prevent him from avenging the death of his brother, Lucius. * [[Junia Calvina]] (d. after AD 79), married [[Lucius Vitellius the Younger|Lucius Vitellius]], a brother of the future emperor [[Vitellius]]. Accused of incest with her youngest brother, she was exiled by [[Claudius]], only to be recalled ten years later by the emperor [[Nero]]. * [[Decimus Junius Silanus Torquatus]] (d. AD 64), consul in 53, forced by Nero to commit suicide after being accused of boasting of his descent from Augustus. * [[Lucius Junius Silanus Torquatus]] (d. AD 49), praetor in 48, he was engaged to [[Claudia Octavia|Octavia]], daughter of [[Claudius]]. [[Agrippina the Younger|Agrippina]] spread a rumor that he had committed incest with his sister, as a result of which he was expelled from the Senate and deprived of his office. He committed suicide on the day that Claudius and Agrippina were married. * [[Junia Lepida]], who married Gaius Cassius Longinus, and raised her nephew [[Lucius Junius Silanus Torquatus]] the younger (50-66), after his father Marcus was murdered.Barrett, Anthony, ''Caligula: The Corruption of Power'' (Touchstone, 1989), p.viii-ix. * [[Junia Silana]] (d. AD 59), died in exile after a feud with Agrippina.Gem√§√ü R. Hanslik, Iunius 27. I. Silana, in: Der Kleine Pauly, Bd. 2 (1967), Sp. 1561. ==See also== *[[Junia (gens)]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Gaius Rubellius Blandus]],
and [[Marcus Vipstanus Gallus]]|as=Suffect consuls}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of early imperial Roman consuls|Consul]] of the [[Roman Empire]]|regent1=[[Lucius Norbanus Balbus]],
followed by [[Publius Petronius (consul 19)|Publius Petronius]]|years=19}} {{s-aft|after=[[Marcus Valerius Messalla (Consul 20)|Marcus Valerius Messala]],
and [[Marcus Aurelius Cotta Maximus Messalinus]]|as=Ordinary consuls}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Junius Silanus Torquatus, Marcus}} [[Category:Junii|Silanus, Decimus]] [[Category:Imperial Roman consuls]] [[Category:Roman governors of Africa]] [[Category:1st-century Romans]]

{{More citations needed|date=January 2019}} {{Use American English|date=January 2019}} {{Short description|Chinese characters sharing the same phonetic character component}} A '''xiesheng''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|Ë´ßËÅ≤}}|p=xi√©shƒìng}}) or '''phonological series''' is a set of Chinese characters sharing the same sound-based element.{{Cite journal|last=Pan|first=Wuyun|date=2015-12-30|title=Xi√©shƒìng Ë´ßËÅ≤ (Phonetic Series)|url=https://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopedia-of-chinese-language-and-linguistics/xiesheng-phonetic-series-COM_00000467|journal=Encyclopedia of Chinese Language and Linguistics|language=en|volume=|pages=|via=Brill Online}} Characters belonging to these series are generally [[Chinese character classification#Phono-semantic compound characters|phono-semantic compounds]], where the character is composed of a semantic element (or [[Radical (Chinese character)|radical]]) and a sound-based element, encoding information about the meaning and the pronunciation respectively.{{Cite journal|last=Smith|first=Jonathan|title=A/B Type Segregation in Mixed-Onset Phonetic Series is the Key to Early Chinese Onset Complexity|url=https://www.academia.edu/37960569/A_B_Type_Segregation_in_Mixed-Onset_Phonetic_Series_is_the_Key_to_Early_Chinese_Onset_Complexity|journal=Cahiers de Linguistique Asie Orientale|language=en}} For example, the character {{lang|zh|{{linktext|Ê≥¢}}}} is composed of the semantic component {{linktext|Ê∞µ}} 'water' and the sound component {{lang|zh|{{linktext|ÁöÆ}}}} (believed to have been pronounced something like *ba). Thus, Ê≥¢ represents a word which has to do with water and was pronounced something like *ba. In fact, the word which Ê≥¢ represents means 'wave' and was pronounced like *pa in Middle Chinese. By grouping together characters with the same sound component into a Xiesheng series, one is able to compare words that were perceived to be quite similar in pronunciation at the time that the characters for these words were invented. As an example, Xiesheng series 25 from [[Bernhard Karlgren]]'s ''[[Grammata Serica Recensa]]'' is reproduced below, with Middle Chinese readings in [[Baxter's transcription for Middle Chinese|Baxter's transcription system]]: * a [[wikt:ÁöÆ|ÁöÆ]] bje * d [[wikt:Áñ≤|Áñ≤]] bje * e [[wikt:Ë¢´|Ë¢´]] bjeX * i [[wikt:ÈôÇ|ÈôÇ]] pje * j [[wikt:Êä´|Êä´]] phje * l [[wikt:Ê≥¢|Ê≥¢]] pa * m [[wikt:Ë∑õ|Ë∑õ]] paX * n [[wikt:Á∞∏|Á∞∏]] paX * n [[wikt:Á∞∏|Á∞∏]] paH * o [[wikt:Á†¥|Á†¥]] phaH * q [[wikt:Â©Ü|Â©Ü]] ba == References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * [[wiktionary:Wiktionary:About_Chinese/phonetic_series|Phonetic series on Wiktionary]] * {{Cite book|title=‰∏äÂè§Èü≥Á≥ª|last=Zhengzhang (ÈÑ≠Âºµ)|first=Shangfang (Â∞öËä≥)|publisher=Shanghai Education Press|year=2003|isbn=9787532092444|location=[[Shanghai]]|pages=|trans-title=Old Chinese Phonology|author-link=Zhengzhang Shangfang}} {{ling-stub}} {{SinoTibetan-lang-stub}} [[Category:Chinese characters]]

RLP 12-304 | producer = [[Orrin Keepnews]] | prev_title = [[Way Out! (album)|Way Out!]] | prev_year = 1958 | next_title = [[The Big Soul-Band]] | next_year = 1960 }} {{album reviews |rev2 = ''[[The Rolling Stone Jazz Record Guide]]'' | rev2Score = {{rating|5|5}}{{Cite book |editor-last=Swenson |editor-first=J. | author-link = | year = 1985 | title = The Rolling Stone Jazz Record Guide | publisher = Random House/Rolling Stone | location = USA | isbn = 0-394-72643-X | pages = 89 }} }} '''''The Little Giant''''' is an album by [[jazz]] saxophonist [[Johnny Griffin]] and his all-star sextet, released on the [[Riverside Records|Riverside]] label in 1959. It was Griffin's third album on Riverside. ==Track listing== #"Olive Refractions" ([[Norman Simmons (musician)|Norman Simmons]]) - 4:17 #"The Message" (Simmons) - 7:24 #"Lonely One" ([[Babs Gonzales]]) 4:09 #"63rd Street Theme" (Griffin) - 7:35 #"Playmates" ([[Saxie Dowell]]) - 4:19 #"Venus and the Moon" (Simmons) - 6:32 ==Personnel== *[[Johnny Griffin]] ‚Äî tenor saxophone *[[Wynton Kelly]] ‚Äî piano *[[Blue Mitchell]] ‚Äî trumpet *[[Julian Priester]] ‚Äî trombone *[[Sam Jones (musician)|Sam Jones]] ‚Äî bass *[[Albert Heath]] ‚Äî drums == References == {{Reflist}} {{Johnny Griffin}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Little Giant}} [[Category:1959 albums]] [[Category:Wynton Kelly albums]] [[Category:Blue Mitchell albums]] [[Category:Johnny Griffin albums]] {{1950s-jazz-album-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Maria Alexandrova |native_name = –ú–∞—Ä–∏—è –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–∞ |native_name_lang = Russian |image = –ú–∞—Ä–∏—è –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–∞ –≤ –±–∞–ª–µ—Ç–µ "–î–æ–Ω –ö–∏—Ö–æ—Ç".jpg |imagesize = 300px |caption = Maria Alexandrova in ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'', [[Bolshoi Theatre]], 2011 |birth_name = Maria Aleksandrovna Alexandrova |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|7|20|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|RSFSR]] [[Soviet Union|USSR]] |education = [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]] |occupation = [[Ballerina]] |employer = [[Bolshoi Theatre]] |known for = |awards = [[Golden Mask (Russian award)|Golden Mask]] (2004)
[[Honoured Artist of Russia|Meritorious Artist]] of Russia (2005)
[[People's Artist of Russia]] (2009) }} '''Maria Alexandrova''' ({{lang-ru|–ú–∞—Ä–∏ÃÅ—è –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞ÃÅ–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–∞ –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞ÃÅ–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–∞}}) is a Russian [[principal dancer]] of the [[Bolshoi Ballet]], [[People‚Äôs Artist]] of Russia. ==Biography== Maria Alexandrova was born in [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]], and attended the [[Moscow Choreographic Academy]]. She won a gold medal at the [[Moscow International Ballet Competition]] in 1997 and shortly thereafter joined the Bolshoi Ballet, quickly making her debut as Myrtha in ''[[Giselle]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/142/ |title=Maria Alexandrova |publisher=[[Bolshoi Ballet]]|accessdate=16 January 2019}} In June 2000 she played a double role in ''[[Don Quixote]]'' as street dancer for the first act and as soloist in third.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jun/23/entertainment/ca-43881|author=Lewis Segal|title=The Bolshoi Steps Back|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 23, 2000|accessdate=16 January 2019}} By 2004 she had become a principal dancer, and since then she has performed in such ballets as ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' and played the title character in [[Alexei Ratmansky]]'s ''Leah'' and Carmen in ''[[Carmen Suite (ballet)|Carmen Suite]]''. In 2005 and 2007 she performed numerous [[solo (dance)|solo]]ist roles and made her debuts as Odette-Odile in ''[[Swan Lake]]'', Medora in ''[[Le Corsaire]]'' and the Pupil in ''[[The Lesson]]''. In 2008 she participated in the premiere of Ratmansky's ''[[Flames of Paris]]'', in which she played the heroine Jeanne.{{cite web|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/235/roles/#20080703190000 |title=Flames of Paris premiere cast list|publisher=[[Bolshoi Theatre]]|accessdate=12 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archivedate=September 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912205655/http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/235/roles/}} In 2009 she danced in the premiere of ''[[Copp√©lia]]'' as Swanilda,{{cite web|title=Coppelia premiere cast list|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/283/roles/#20090312190000|publisher=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=12 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archivedate=September 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912212321/http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/283/roles/ }} made her debut as Nikiya in ''[[La Bayad√®re]]'' and danced the title role in the premiere of ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|Esmeralda]]''.{{cite web|title=Esmeralda premiere cast list|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/343/roles/#20091225190000|publisher=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=12 September 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912205941/http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/343/roles/|deadurl=yes|archivedate=September 12, 2014}} The same year she also traveled to [[Novosibirsk]] where she appeared again in ''Swan Lake'' and ''Don Quixote'', both of which were performed at the [[Novosibirsk Opera and Ballet Theatre]]. In 2010 she made her debut as the Countess in [[Roland Petit]]'s ''Queen of Spades''. On 2 August 2013, during a performance by the Bolshoi Ballet at the [[Royal Opera House]] in [[London]], Alexandrova injured her leg while performing Gamzatti in ''La Bayad√®re'' and had to leave the stage without finishing her act.{{cite news|url=http://en.itar-tass.com/non-political/698125|title=Bolshoi prima Maria Alexandrova gets injury at guest performance in London|agency=[[TASS]]|date=August 3, 2013|accessdate=16 January 2019}} She returned to the Bolshoi stage on February 28, 2014 in a performance of [[Mats Ek]]'s ''Apartment''.{{cite web|title=Apartment cast list |url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/616/roles/#20140228190000|publisher=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=12 September 2014|deadurl=yes |archivedate=September 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912213233/http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/performances/616/roles/}} In 2015 Maria Alexandrova had participated in a film called ''[[Bolshoi Babylon]]''.{{cite news|author=Kourlas, Gia|date=December 18, 2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/19/arts/dance/maria-alexandrova-on-the-bolshoi-we-still-dont-know-the-truth.html|title=Maria Alexandrova on the Bolshoi: ‚ÄòWe Still Don‚Äôt Know the Truth‚Äô|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=16 January 2019}} On 2 February 2017, it was officially announced that Ms. Alexandrova decided to resign from the Bolshoi Ballet. "Bolshoi Theater has confirmed resignation of one of the ballet company stars, internationally acclaimed prima ballerina Maria Alexandrova. The resignation was voluntary, it said. "On January 19, 2017, People‚Äôs Artist of Russia Maria Alexandrova filed a request for voluntary resignation," a spokesperson for the theater said. "This was Ms. Alexandrova‚Äôs personal decision."{{cite news|date=February 3, 2013|accessdate=16 January 2019|url=http://tass.com/society/928775|title=Bolshoi confirms resignation of prima ballerina Maria Alexandrova|agency=TASS}} Maria Alexandrova explained she will continue to dance within the context of other projects. Alexandrova was a leader of the Bolshoi Theatre's performer's union, and on 14 September 2014 she ran unsuccessfully for [[Moscow City Duma election, 2014|election]] to the [[Moscow City Duma]] as a candidate from the [[Communist Party of the Russian Federation]], finishing second in the 41st electoral district.{{cite web|title=41st electoral district|url=http://www.–∫—Ä–∞—Å–Ω–∞—è–º–æ—Å–∫–≤–∞.—Ä—Ñ/area41|work=[[Krasnaya Moskva (newspaper)|Krasnaya Moskva]]|accessdate=12 September 2014|archivedate=August 11, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811211024/http://xn--80aaah1bcnglpme3p.xn--p1ai/area41|deadurl=yes|language=ru}}{{cite web|title=Results of elections to the Moscow City Duma held on 14 September 2014|url=http://vybory.mosgorizbirkom.ru/#!/candidates |website=Moscow Electoral Commission|accessdate=16 January 2019|language=ru}} ==See also== *[[List of Russian ballet dancers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/142/ Page Alexandrova's on Bolshoi Theatre] *[http://www.bolshoi.org/stars/alexandrova/prima-eng.htm Page Alexandrova's on Adajio.ru] *[http://www.bolshoi.org/stars/alexandrova/photo-eng.htm Photo Alexandrova's on Adajio.ru] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081016014521/http://www.ballerinagallery.com/alexandrova.htm Photo Alexandrova's on The Ballerina Gallery] *[http://gallery-mt.narod.ru/pages-b/aleksandrova.html Photo Alexandrova's on The Gallery of Masters of Musical Theatre] {{Russia in the Eurovision Young Dancers}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alexandrova, Maria}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Bolshoi Ballet principal dancers]] [[Category:Honored Artists of the Russian Federation]] [[Category:Moscow State Academy of Choreography alumni]] [[Category:People from Moscow]] [[Category:People's Artists of Russia]] [[Category:Russian ballerinas]] [[Category:21st-century ballet dancers]]

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=June 2018}} {{more footnotes|date=June 2018}} }} '''Maria Yevgenevna Allash''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: –ú–∞—Ä–∏—è –ï–≤–≥–µ–Ω—å–µ–≤–Ω–∞ –ê–ª–ª–∞—à) (born 9 March 1976) is a Russian ballet dancer, and [[Bolshoi Ballet#Principal dancers|principal dancer]] of the [[Bolshoi Ballet]] since 1994.
Born in [[Moscow]], then part of the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]], in the [[Soviet Union]], Allash joined the [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]], under the tutelage of Professor [[Sofia Golovkina]]. Since 1994 she has been a soloist of the Bolshoi Theatre. She has been tutored at different times by Tatyana Golikova and Nina Semizorova. She is married to fellow Bolshoi soloist [[Alexei Loparevich]]. She has been honoured with the titles [[Merited Artist of the Russian Federation|Honoured Artist of Russia]], in 2002, and [[People's Artist of Russia]] in 2012. Since 2017 she has been under working under contract at the Bolshoi.
==Repertoire== Allash's first appearance was in 1994, dancing the [[mazurka]] in the eleventh waltz in ''[[Chopiniana]]''. The following year she appeared as the Dryad ruler in [[Don Quixote (ballet)|''Don Quixote'']], as Countess Cherry in ''[[Cipollino]]'', as Mirta in ''[[Giselle]]'' and as Aegina in [[Spartacus (ballet)|''Spartacus'']]. Allash has gone on to appear in a number of ballet productions, including ''[[La Bayad√®re]]'', [[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|''The Sleeping Beauty'']], ''[[Swan Lake]]'', ''[[Raymonda]]'', ''[[Mozartiana]]'', ''The Legend of Love'', ''[[The Little Humpbacked Horse (ballet)|The Little Humpbacked Horse]]'', ''[[Symphony in C (ballet)|Symphony in C]]'', ''[[The Golden Age (Shostakovich)|The Golden Age]]'', ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream (ballet)|A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|La Esmeralda]]'', ''[[Paquita]]'' and ''[[Jewels (ballet)|Jewels]]''.
==Tours== In 2006 Allash participated in the festival "Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet", staged at the [[Krasnoyarsk State Opera and Ballet Theatre]], and performed as Gamzatti in ''La Bayad√®re'' and Kitri in ''Don Quixote''. She again performed in Krasnoyarsk in 2007, once more in ''La Bayad√®re'', this time as Nikiya, and as Aegina in ''Spartacus'', choreographed by [[Yury Grigorovich]]. Later that year she performed at a gala concert at the [[Royal Opera House]] in London in honour of the 80th birthday of Yury Grigorovich. Allash performed at the Kazan International Classical Ballet Festival in 2008, appearing at the [[Tatar Academic Opera and Ballet Theatre]] as Odette/Odile in ''Swan Lake'', and as Fairy Lilacs in ''The Sleeping Beauty''. Allash participated in the XIII Festival of Classical Ballet in 2016, reprising her role as Nikiya in ''La Bayad√®re'' at the Samara Academic Opera and Ballet Theatre.
==References== *[https://www.bolshoi.ru/persons/ballet/97/ Maria Allash] at the Bolshoi Theatre
{{DEFAULTSORT:Allash, Maria}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Moscow]] [[Category:Bolshoi Ballet principal dancers]] [[Category:Russian ballerinas]] [[Category:People's Artists of Russia]] [[Category:Moscow State Academy of Choreography alumni]] [[Category:20th-century ballet dancers]] [[Category:21st-century ballet dancers]]

'''Anna Antonicheva''' ({{lang-ru|–ê–Ω–Ω–∞ –ê–Ω–∞—Ç–æ–ª—å–µ–≤–Ω–∞ –ê–Ω—Ç–æ–Ω–∏—á–µ–≤–∞}}) is a [[ballerina]] and [[People's Artist of Russia]],<ref name=bolshoi>{{cite web|url=https://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/107/|title=Anna Antonicheva|publisher=[[Bolshoi Ballet]]|accessdate=29 June 2019}}</ref> who was a [[principal dancer]] of [[Bolshoi Ballet]].
==Biography== Antonicheva was born in 1973 in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]], and was a graduate of the [[Baku Ballet School]].<ref name=ballerinagallery>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballerinagallery.com/antonich.htm |title=Anna Antonicheva|accessdate=29 June 2019}}</ref> In 1988, she won both the gold medal and the audience prize at the [[1st Transcaucasian Competition of Ballet Dancers]]. Subsequently she studied at the [[Moscow Choreographic Academy]], graduating in 1991. The same year, she joined [[Bolshoi Theatre]], where she performed roles such as the Hungarian Bride in ''[[Swan Lake]]'', Shireen in ''[[Legend of Love (ballet)|Legend of Love]]'', Phrygia in ''[[Spartacus (ballet)|Spartacus]]'' and Myrtha in ''[[Giselle]]''. In 1997, she made debuts as Princess Aurora and Princess Florine in ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' and the same year danced as Henriette in ''[[Raymonda]]'' and Nikiya in ''[[La Bayad√®re]]''.<ref name=bolshoi/>
In 1999 she went on a tour to [[Kyrgyzstan]] where she danced in ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'' with [[Dmitry Belogolovtsev]], and in 2000 she traveled to [[Japan]] where she appeared in ''La Bayad√®re'' at the [[New National Theatre Tokyo]] with [[Carlos Acosta]]. She first danced the title role in ''Giselle'' in 1999 and Odette-Odile in [[Yuri Grigorovich]]'s production of ''Swan Lake'' in 2001. She portrayed Raymonda in 2003 and the same year appeared as Esmeralda in [[Roland Petit]]'s ''[[Notre Dame de Paris (ballet)|Notre-Dame de Paris]]''. In 2004 she performed in [[George Balanchine]]'s ''[[Concerto Barocco]]'' and ''[[Agon (ballet)|Agon]]'', and in 2005 danced Titania in [[John Neumeier]]'s ''A Midsummer Night's Dream''. In 2006 Antonicheva performed Rita in ''[[The Golden Age (Shostakovich)|The Golden Age]]'' and in 2007 played Medora in ''[[Le Corsaire]]'' and danced in Balanchine's [[Serenade (ballet)|Serenade]]. In 2008 she originated the role of Mireille de Poitiers in [[Alexei Ratmansky]]'s production of ''[[Flames of Paris]]'', and in 2010 she danced [[William Forsythe (choreographer)|William Forsythe]]'s ''Herman Schmerman''.<ref name=bolshoi/>
Antonicheva departed the Bolshoi Ballet in 2017.<ref name=bolshoi/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Antonicheva, Anna}} [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian ballerinas]] [[Category:People from Baku]] [[Category:Bolshoi Ballet principal dancers]] [[Category:20th-century ballet dancers]] [[Category:21st-century ballet dancers]]
{{ballet-stub}} {{Russia-bio-stub}}

[[File:Belogolovtsev Abderahman.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Belogolovtsev performing as Abderahman in the Bolshoi's production of ''[[Raymonda]]'' in 2010]] '''Dmitry Vladimirovich Belogolovtsev''' ({{lang-ru|–î–º–∏—Ç—Ä–∏–π –í–ª–∞–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∏—á –ë–µ–ª–æ–≥–æ–ª–æ–≤—Ü–µ–≤}}) (born 26 November 1973) is a Russian ballet dancer, and former [[Bolshoi Ballet#Principal dancers|principal dancer]] of the [[Bolshoi Ballet]].
Born in [[Lviv]], then part of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]], in the [[Soviet Union]], Belogolovtsev joined the [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]] in 1992, under the tutelage of Professor [[Alexander Bondarenko]]. He graduated in 1995, and joined the Bolshoi Ballet. He has taken part on various international projects, dancing alongside [[Nina Ananiashvili]], [[Nadezhda Gracheva]], and [[Anna Antonicheva]]. In 1993 he was award third prize and the bronze medal at the International Ballet Competition in Moscow, and in 1998 won the second prize at the [[USA International Ballet Competition]]. Also in 1998 he was awarded the title of [[Merited Artist of the Russian Federation|Honoured Artist of Russia]]. Between 2000 and 2004 he appeared alongside Nina Ananiashvili and Alexei Fadeechev in adaptations of [[Stanton Welch]]'s ballets ''Green'' and ''Between Heaven and Earth'', and [[Alexei Ratmansky]]'s ''The Charms of Mannerism'' and ''Dreams of Japan''.
Belogolovtsev was nominated for the "[[Golden Mask (Russian award)|Golden Mask]]" for "Best Actor in the Ballet" in 2000, for his performance in the lead role in ''Afternoon Rest of the Faun''. In 2003 he played Ferhad in ''Legend of Love'', for which he was nominated for the ''[[Prix Benois de la Danse]]''. Between 2004 and 2015 he performed with [[Sergei Filin]] and [[Anna Antonicheva]] in the [[Mayakovsky Theatre]]'s ''Love Through the Eyes of a Detective.'' In 2008 he was honoured as a [[People's Artist of Russia]].

revision.text:
{{Eastern Slavic name|Konstantinovich|Gudanov}} {{Infobox person |name = Dmitry Gudanov |image = File:–î–º–∏—Ç—Ä–∏–π –ì—É–¥–∞–Ω–æ–≤.jpg |imagesize = 300px |caption = Dmitry Gudanov as Albrecht in "[[Giselle]]", [[Bolshoi Theatre]], 21 January 2011 |birth_name = –î–º–∏—Ç—Ä–∏–π –ö–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–Ω–æ–≤–∏—á –ì—É–¥–∞–Ω–æ–≤ |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|7|9|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] |education = [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]] |occupation = [[Principal dancer]] |employer = [[Bolshoi Theatre]] |known for = |awards = [[Honoured Artist of Russia|Meritorious Artist]] of Russia (2005), [[People's Artist of Russia]] (2012) }}
'''Dmitry Konstantinovich Gudanov''' ({{lang-ru|–î–º–∏—Ç—Ä–∏–π –ö–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç–∏–Ω–æ–≤–∏—á –ì—É–¥–∞–Ω–æ–≤}}) is a [[People's Artist of Russia]] and [[principal dancer]] of [[Bolshoi Ballet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mariinsky.ru/en/company/guest_ballet/gudanov05/ |title=Dmitry Gudanov (Bolshoi Ballet, Moscow) |publisher=[[Mariinsky Theatre]] |accessdate=October 11, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219215832/http://www.mariinsky.ru/en/company/guest_ballet/gudanov05/ |archivedate=December 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He retired from the Bolshoi in July 2017.
==Early life and awards== Gudanov was born 9 July 1975 in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. From 1985 to 1994 he attended [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography|Moscow Academic Choreography College]], a class of [[Leonid Zhdanov]], from which he graduated by 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bolshoi.org/stars/gudanov/prima-eng.htm|title=Dmitry Gudanov |website=Bolshoi.org|accessdate=October 11, 2013}}</ref> After that, he joined ''Bolshoi Ballet'' and performed in his first act as one of the ''boys'' in the ''[[La Sylphide]]'' and in 1995 played a role of a male ''French doll'' in ''[[the Nutcracker]]''. In 1996 he won a ''Danse Noble'' prize at the [[Perm]]ian [[Open Competition for Russian Ballet Dancers]] and in 1998 received a [[gold medal]] at the [[International Competition for Ballet Dancers]] in [[Paris]].<ref name=bolshoi>{{cite web|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/136/|title=Dmitry Gudanov|publisher=[[Bolshoi Ballet]]|accessdate=October 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Career== In 1999 he appeared in a play called ''[[Romeo and Juliet (ballet)|Romeo and Juliet]]'' as ''Mercutio'' and the same year have been seen as ''Count Albrecht'' in ''[[Giselle]]''. Also the same year, he played a role of ''James'' in ''La Sylphide'' a play in which he performed five years earlier and was awarded ''Moscow Debuts Festival'' prize. In 2000 he reprised his role in ''the Nutcracker'' as a ''Nutcracker-Prince'' and the same year was awarded ''Soul of Dance'' prize from the [[Ballet (magazine)|Ballet]]. In 2002 he played a role of ''Colas'' in the ''[[La Fille mal gardee]]'' and in 2003 he participated at one of the [[Notre Dame de Paris]] [[opera]]s where he played a role of ''Claude Frollo''. From 1998 to 2002 he played many solo acts and in 1999 was awarded the ''Moscow Debuts Festival'' prize for one of his solo roles.<ref name=bolshoi/>
During the same 2002 and later 2003 he played a ''prince'' in ''[[the Nutcracker]]'' with [[Yelena Andrienko]] being his partner and with assistance of [[Canadian Ballet]]. The same year he appeared in ''[[Les Sylphides|Chopiniana]]'' which was performed in [[Kazan]] at the [[Rudolph Nureyev International Festival of Classical Ballet]].<ref name=bolshoi/>
His solo acts were finished for some time, till 2007. In between those years, he appeared as ''Prince Desire'' in the ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|Sleeping Beauty]]'', ''Hermann'' in the [[The Queen of Spades (opera)|Queen of Spades]], and ''Prince Siegfried'' in the ''[[Swan Lake]]'' all which he played in one year of 2004. In 2005, Gudanov was awarded ''Merited Artist of the Russian Federation'' award and the same year appeared in both as a ''miller'' in the ''Le Tricorne'' and ''Basilio'' in ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]''. In 2006, he appeared in a play called ''[[Cinderella (Fitinhof-Schell)|Cinderella]] as a lovely ''Prince'' and the same year played as ''Solor'' in the ''[[La Bayad√®re]]''. In 2007, he performed an act of a ''[[teacher]]'' in ''[[the Lesson]]'' and two years later appeared as ''Phoebus'' in [[La Esmeralda (ballet)|Esmeralda]].<ref name=bolshoi/>
==See also== * [[List of Russian ballet dancers]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/136/ Page Gudanov's on the website Bolshoi Theatre]
{{Authority control}}

{{Eastern Slavic name|Aleksandrovna|Lunkina}} {{Infobox person |name = Svetlana Lunkina |image = Swan Lake Lunkina.jpg |imagesize = 300px |caption = Svetlana Lunkina as Odette in [[Swan Lake]], [[Bolshoi Theatre]], 22 May 2011 |birth_name = –°–≤–µ—Ç–ª–∞–Ω–∞ –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–∞ –õ—É–Ω—å–∫–∏–Ω–∞ |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1979|7|29}} |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] (now Russia) |education = [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]] |occupation = [[Ballerina]] |employer = [[Bolshoi Theatre]], [[National Ballet of Canada]] |known for = [[Giselle]], [[Swan Lake]] |awards = [[Honoured Artist of Russia|Meritorious Artist]] of Russia (2008), [[Prix Benois de la Danse]] (2007) |website = {{URL|https://svetlanalunkina.com}} }}
'''Svetlana Aleksandrovna Lunkina''' ({{lang-ru|–°–≤–µ—Ç–ª–∞–Ω–∞ –ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–∞ –õ—É–Ω—å–∫–∏–Ω–∞}}; born 29 July 1979) is a Russian [[Ballet dancer|ballerina]] who is a [[principal dancer]] with the [[National Ballet of Canada]].<ref name=russian_nationalballet>{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Deirdre|title=Ballerina Svetlana Lunkina: from Russia, with star power|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/ballerina-svetlana-lunkina-from-russia-with-star-power/article15535936/|website=The Globe and Mail|publisher=The Globe and Mail Inc.|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== Svetlana Lunkina was born in [[Moscow]] and attended the [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography|Moscow Choreographic Academy]]. Upon her graduation in 1997, she joined the [[Bolshoi Ballet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/78/|title=Svetlana Lunkina|publisher=Bolshoi Ballet|accessdate=8 October 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206040700/http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/78/|archivedate=6 February 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> During her first season at the Bolshoi Theatre she was chosen to perform the title role in ''[[Giselle]]'' and thus, at the age of 18, became the youngest Giselle in the history of the Bolshoi.<ref name="Balancing Act">{{cite news|last1=Crabb|first1=Michael|title=Balancing Act|url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/january-2014/Balancing-Act|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=Dance Magazine|issue=January 2014}}</ref>
Over her 15-year career with the company, Lunkina danced many leading roles in both classical and contemporary ballets. In 2001 she was a Triumph Youth Award recipient, and the following year, [[Alexander Grant (dancer)|Alexander Grant]] set the role of Lise in [[Frederick Ashton]]'s ''[[La fille mal gard√©e (Ashton)|La Fille mal gard√©e]]'' on her. Later she worked extensively with [[Roland Petit]], who gave her the roles of Liza in ''La Dame de Pique'' and Esmeralda in ''Notre-Dame de Paris'' in their Bolshoi premieres. She also performed his ''La Rose Malade'', which Petit updated for Lunkina for the first time since [[Maya Plisetskaya]] danced it. She was promoted to the rank of principal dancer in 2005. Lunkina was awarded Brilliance of the 21st Century award the same year. In 2010 she was awarded with the prize Ballerina of the Decade,<ref name=nb>{{cite web|url=http://national.ballet.ca/thecompany/principals/Svetlana_Lunkina/|title=Svetlana Lunkina|publisher=[[National Ballet of Canada]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824231931/http://national.ballet.ca/thecompany/principals/Svetlana_Lunkina/|archivedate=24 August 2013|accessdate=20 February 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> along with the three other well-known ballerinas: [[Diana Vishneva]], [[Alina Cojocaru]] and [[Lucia Lacarra]]. During her career she also performed in such ballets as ''[[The Nutcracker]]'', [[Don Quixote (ballet)|''Don Quixote'']] and [[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|''The Sleeping Beauty'']], and appeared at such theatres as the [[Berlin State Opera|Berlin]] and [[Vienna State Opera]]s, and with the [[Paris Opera Ballet]], among others.<ref name=nb/>
In 2002, Lunkina played one of the main characters in the feature film ''St.Petersburg-Cannes Express'', by the American director [[John Daly (producer)|John Daly]]; the world premiere screening took place in 2003 in [[Palm Springs]], [[California]].<ref name="imdb">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0296522/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm|title=The Petersburg-Cannes Express (2003) - Full Cast & Crew|website=IMDb|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> In 2004, the Japanese portrait photographer Eichiro Sakata, included Lunkina in his photo gallery called "Piercing the Sky" as an outstanding contemporary personality.<ref name="svetlanalunkina">{{cite web|url=http://svetlanalunkina.com/biography/|title=Biography | –°–≤–µ—Ç–ª–∞–Ω–∞ –õ—É–Ω—å–∫–∏–Ω–∞|website=svetlanalunkina.com|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> In 2013 Lunkina became the main attraction and the ‚Äúobjet d'art‚Äù of a European art exhibit, created by the artist [[Anna Gaskell]].
Lunkina joined the National Ballet of Canada as a principal guest artist<ref name=russian_nationalballet/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://national.ballet.ca/uploadedFiles/MediaReleases/Svetlana%20Lunkina%20and%20Evan%20McKie%20New%20Principal%20Guest%20Artists(1).pdf|title=2013/14 Season Roster: Svetlana Lunkina and Evan McKie Principal Guest Artists|publisher=National Ballet of Canada|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> in August 2013 and as a permanent principal dancer the following year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glassman|first1=Dana|title=A Fresh Start|url=http://www.pointemagazine.com/svetlana-lunkina-2412821431.html|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=Pointe Magazine|issue=December 2014}}</ref> In 2014 she was invited as a guest dancer in [[South Korea]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201406012128295&code=990105|title=[Í∏∞ÏûêÎ©îÎ™®]Í≥ÑÏïΩÎèÑ ÏïàÎêú Ï∂úÏó∞ÏßÑ ÎÇ¥ÏÑ∏Ïö¥ ÏûÖÏû•Í∂å ÌåêÎß§|newspaper=''[[Kyunghyang Shinmun]]''|accessdate=23 June 2014|archivedate=23 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140623042617/http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201406012128295&code=990105|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> and in April 2015 she performed in Taiwan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=Diane|title=Flying feet and crossed fingers|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2015/04/16/2003616026|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=Taipei Times|date=16 April 2015}}</ref>
Lunkina is the artistic director of the Canada All Star Ballet Gala. Its first performance took place on 11 February 2017 at the [[Sony Centre for the Performing Arts]] in Toronto, featuring principal dancers from [[American Ballet Theatre]], the Bolshoi Ballet, Rome Opera Ballet, [[Royal Ballet]], [[Royal Danish Ballet]], [[San Francisco Ballet]], [[Stuttgart Ballet]] and the National Ballet of Canada.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Deirdre|title=Canada All Star Ballet Gala|url=http://nuvomagazine.com/art/canada-all-star-ballet-gala|accessdate=21 February 2017|work=Nuvo Magazine|date=23 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gala Program Book|url=http://canadaallstar.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Book3.pdf|website=Canada All Star Ballet Gala|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Lunkina has two children: Maxim, born in January 2004, and Eva, born in April 2009.<ref name="Balancing Act"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Ruslan Skvortsov | image = RuslanSkvortsov.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = Ruslan Skvortsov as Prince Siegfried in ''Swan Lake''. Bolshoi Theatre. 2011 | birth_name = –†—É—Å–ª–∞–Ω –í–∞—Å–∏–ª—å–µ–≤–∏—á –°–∫–≤–æ—Ä—Ü–æ–≤ | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|01|31|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Yelets]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] (now Russia) | citizenship = Russian Federation | height = 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) | education = [[Moscow Choreographic Academy]] | occupation = [[Ballet dancer]] | years active = 1998 to present | employer = [[Bolshoi Theatre]] | awards = [[Merited Artist of the Russian Federation|Meritorious Artist]] of Russia (2014) | website = }}
'''Ruslan Skvortsov''' ({{lang-ru|–†—É—Å–ª–∞–Ω –í–∞—Å–∏–ª—å–µ–≤–∏—á –°–∫–≤–æ—Ä—Ü–æ–≤}}; born 31 January 1980)<ref>{{cite web|title=Skvortsov, Ruslan Vasilyevich|url=http://theatreinform.ru/bd/Actor/Details.php?A_Code=4060|website=Actors of Russia Database|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> is a Russian [[principal dancer]] of the [[Bolshoi Ballet]].
==Biography== Ruslan Skvortsov was born in [[Yelets]], [[Lipetsk Oblast]], where he received his early training from Elena Timofeyeva,<ref>{{cite news|title=–û–±—â–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∏–∫–∏ –æ—Ü–µ–Ω–∏–ª–∏ –≤ –ï–ª—å—Ü–µ –∫–∞—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ –æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è –≤ —Å—Ñ–µ—Ä–µ –∏—Å–∫—É—Å—Å—Ç–≤|url=http://vesti-lipetsk.ru/obshhestvenniki-ocenili-v-elce-kachestvo-obrazovaniya-v-sfere-iskusstv/|accessdate=10 April 2017|work=Vesti Lipetsk|date=22 March 2017}}</ref> and then studied at the [[Moscow Choreographic Academy]] with Vyacheslav Mikhaylov.<ref name=skvortsovbt>{{cite web|title=Ruslan Skvortsov|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/en/persons/ballet/114/|website=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> Upon his graduation in 1998 he joined the Bolshoi Ballet, where he has worked under the tutelage of [[Valery Lagunov]] and [[Nikolai Fadeyechev]]. In 2001 he was awarded a bronze medal at the Moscow International Ballet Competition. He was appointed to the rank of principal dancer in October 2009<ref>{{cite web|title=news feed for 15 October 2009|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/about/press/articles/2009/|website=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> and was awarded the title of [[Merited Artist of the Russian Federation|Meritorious Artist]] of Russia in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=news feed for 30 April 2014|url=http://www.bolshoi.ru/about/press/articles/2014/|website=Bolshoi Theatre|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
Skvortsov made his debut as the soloist of the Fourth Movmement of [[George Balanchine]]'s ''[[Symphony in C (ballet)|Symphony in C]]'' in 1999 and danced his first leading role in an evening-length ballet, Little Count Cherry in ''Cipollino'', in 2000, followed by the Poet in [[Michel Fokine]]'s ''[[Les Sylphides|Chopiniana]]'' in 2001. He first danced Prince Siegfried in ''[[Swan Lake]]'' in 2002, followed by debuts as Count Albrecht in ''[[Giselle]]'', Lord Wilson/Taor in ''[[The Pharaoh's Daughter]]'', Claude Frollo in [[Roland Petit]]'s ''Notre-Dame de Paris'' and the Ballet Dancer in [[Alexei Ratmansky]]'s ''[[The Limpid Stream|The Bright Stream]]'' in 2003. In 2004 Skvortsov first danced Jean de Brienne in ''[[Raymonda]]'' and Balanchine's ''[[Agon (ballet)|Agon]]'', and in 2005 he performed the Miller in [[L√©onide Massine]]'s [[The Three-Cornered Hat]], the Hero in Massine's ''Les Pr√©sages'' and Demetrius in [[John Neumeier]]'s ''A Midsummer Night's Dream''.<ref name=skvortsovbt/> Further debuts followed as Boris in [[Yuri Grigorovich]]'s ''The Golden Age'' (2006), Don Jos√© in ''[[Carmen Suite (ballet)|Carmen Suite]]'' (2007), James in ''[[La Sylphide]]'' (2008), Prince D√©sir√© in ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' (2008), Conrad in ''[[Le Corsaire]]'' (2009), Romeo in Grigorovich's production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' (2010), the title role in [[John Cranko]]'s ''[[Onegin (Cranko)|Onegin]]'' (2013) and Des Grieux in Neumeier's ''The Lady of the Camellias'' (2014). At the Bolshoi Ballet he was the first to perform the roles of Antoine Mistral in Ratmansky's ''[[Flames of Paris]]'' (2008), Lucien d'Hervilly in Yuri Burlaka's staging of the grand pas from ''[[Paquita]]'' (2008), Frantz in [[Sergei Vikharev]]'s reconstruction of ''[[Copp√©lia]]'' (2009), Phoebus in ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|Esmeralda]]'' (2009), staged by Burlaka and Vasily Medvedev, and My Father, My Hero in [[Maurice B√©jart]]'s ''Ga√Æt√© Parisienne'' (2019). In 2015 he danced the part of Pechorin ("Princess Mary" section) in the world premiere of Yuri Possokhov's ''A Hero of Our Time''. In 2019 he made his debut as Crassus in Grigorovich's ''[[Spartacus (ballet)|Spartacus]]''.<ref name=crassus>{{cite web |title=Bolshoi Newsletter 2018-19, no. 8 |url=http://bolshoinews.com/images/Newsletter/2018_2019/issue08.pdf |website=Bolshoi Theatre |accessdate=18 February 2019}}</ref>
With the Bolshoi Ballet Skvortsov has performed in the United States,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Macaulay|first1=Alastair|title=Deceit, Madness and Love, Imported Directly From Russia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/22/arts/dance/the-bolshoi-ballets-giselle-in-washington.html|accessdate=21 December 2016|work=New York Times|date=21 May 2014}}</ref> Canada,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Crabb|first1=Michael|title=Review: Bolshoi Ballet‚Äôs Swan Lake|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2012/05/16/review_bolshoi_ballets_swan_lake.html|accessdate=21 December 2016|work=Toronto Star|date=16 May 2012}}</ref> Cuba,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lutterbeck|first1=Deborah|title=Bolshoi Ballet in Havana|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SRxYRIqf84|accessdate=13 April 2017|agency=Reuters|date=14 February 2010}}</ref> the United Kingdom,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Crisp|first1=Clement|title=Giselle, Royal Opera House, London|url=https://www.ft.com/content/f80fc1f0-9998-11df-a852-00144feab49a|accessdate=21 December 2016|work=Financial Times|date=27 July 2010}}</ref> France, the Netherlands, Belgium,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haegeman|first1=Marc|title=Silent Triumph of Tradition|url=http://danceviewtimes.com/2006/Winter/08/bolshoi.html|website=Danceview Times|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> Switzerland,<ref>{{cite news|title=Brilliant Gisele ballet performed to boost Russian-Swiss ties|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/culture/2011-02/11/c_13727258.htm|accessdate=21 December Turkey,<ref>{{cite web |title=–ì–∞—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏ –±–∞–ª–µ—Ç–∞ –∏ –æ—Ä–∫–µ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞ –≤ –¢—É—Ä—Ü–∏–∏ |url=https://www.bolshoi.ru/performances/222222/ |website=Bolshoi Theatre |accessdate=25 September Russia|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref> and Australia.<ref name=nboch/> His guest appearances have included performing ''Swan Lake''<ref name=slmar/> at the [[Mariinsky Theatre]] in St. Petersburg,
